• Treaty of Aix-La Chapelle concluded the Austrian War of Succession and the First Carnatic War.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about the 'Second Carnatic War': 
1. Nasir Jung's accession to Hyderabad's throne was the immediate cause of the War. 
2. The French supported the claims of Muzaffar Jang in the Deccan and Chanda Sahib in the Carnatic. 
3. Chanda Sahib and the French defeated and killed Anwarud-din at the Battle of Bidara in 1749. 
How many of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
• Dupleix, the French started interfering in local dynastic disputes to defeat the English. 
• With the death of Nizam-ul-Mulk in 1748 and the release of Chanda Sahib, the son-in-law of Dost Ali, 
the Nawab of Carnatic, he had the opportunity to interfere in local politics. 
Statement 1 is correct 
• The accession of Nasir Jang, the son of the Nizam, to the throne of Hyderabad was opposed by Muzaf
far Jang, the grandson of the Nawab. 
• He claimed the throne, saying that the Mughal Emperor had appointed him as the governor of the Car
natic. 
• Similarly, Chanda Sahib resented the appointment of Anwar-ud-din Khan as the Nawab in the Car
natic. 
Statement 2 is correct 
• The French supported the claims of Muzaffar Jang and Chanda Sahib in the Deccan and Carnatic, 
respectively. 
• The English sided with Nasir Jang and Anwar-ud-din. 
Statement 3 is incorrect 
• In the Battle of Ambur (near Vellore), the combined armies of Muzaffar Jang, Chanda Sahib, and the 
French defeated and killed Anwar-ud-din in 1749. 
• Muzaffar Jang became the subahdar of Deccan, and Dupleix was appointed governor of all the 
Mughal territories south of the River Krishna.  
• A French army under Bussy was stationed in Hyderabad to secure French interests. 
• Territories near Pondicherry and some Orissa coast areas (including Masulipatnam) were ceded to the 
French.

questions.question:
With reference to the Second Carnatic War, consider the following statements: 
1. After an initial defeat, Britishers under Robert Clive attacked and captured Arcot. 
2. The French force surrendered after the murder of Chanda sahib by Muhammed Ali. 
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct   
• After the initial defeat, Robert Clive, an agent ('factor') of the English company, proposed a diversionary 
attack. 
• In August 1751, with only a force of 210 men, Robert Clive attacked and captured Arcot.  
• Chanda Sahib hastened to his capital, taking a force of 4,000 men from Trichinopoly, but failed to return 
the fort even after a siege of 53 days.   
Statement 2 is correct  
• Mysore, Tanjore, and the Maratha chief, Morari Rao, came to the aid of Trichinopoly and of Clive and 
Stringer Lawrence.  
• Trichinopoly was thus relieved of its siege, while General Law of France with Chanda Sahib remained 
cooped up on the island of Srirangam.  
• They were forced to surrender in June 1752 when Muhammad Ali executed Chanda Sahib.  
• Godeheu succeeded Dupleix as the French governor-general in India, adopted a negotiation policy 
with the English, and concluded a treaty. 
• Thus, the treaty of Pondicherry was signed, which recognised Muhammad Ali Khan Walajah as the 
Nawab of the Carnatic.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about the Third Carnatic War: 
1. It was an extension of the Anglo-French War in Europe, which was caused by the Austrian War of 
Succession. 
2. The Battle of Wandiwash in 1760 was a part of the Third Carnatic War. 
3. The British Army under the Command of Robert Clive defeated the French Army under Count Thomas 
Arthur de Lally. 
How many of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect 
• The Third Carnatic War (1758-63) was an extension of the Seven Years War (1756-63) in Europe, which 
started when Austria wanted to recover Silesia in 1756. 
• In 1758, the French army under Count de Lally captured the English forts of St. David and Viziana
garam. 
• The English inflicted heavy losses on the French fleet under Admiral D'Ache at Masulipatnam. 
Statement 2 is correct 
• The battle of Wandiwash was the decisive battle of the Third Carnatic War. 
• It was won by the English in January 1760 at Wandiwash (or Vandavasi) in Tamil Nadu.  
Statement 3 is incorrect 
• General Eyre Coote of the English totally routed the French army under Count Thomas Arthur de Lally 
and took Bussy as a prisoner. 
• Lally defended Pondicherry for eight months before he surrendered in January 1761.  
• Afterward, the French lost Jinji and Mahe and its power was reduced to its lowest.

questions.question:
Consider the following pairs: 
Powers 
Treaty 
1. Treaty of Whitehall Portuguese and British 
2. Treaty of Sutanuti 
3. Treaty of Ryswick  
Mughals and Portuguese 
Dutch and French 
How many of the pairs given above are not correctly matched?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is correct 
• It was a treaty signed by Afonso VI of Portugal and Charles II of England in June 1661 in Whitehall. 
• It was a treaty of Peace and Friendship to establish the marriage of D. Catarina of Braganza to the British 
sovereign. 
• Bombay had been gifted to King Charles II by the King of Portugal as a dowry by this treaty in 1662. 
• Later, Bombay was given over to the East India Company on an annual payment of ten pounds only in 
1668. 
• Bombay was made the headquarters by shifting the seat of the Western Presidency from Surat to Bombay 
in 1687. 
• A different treaty signed at Whitehall on November 1686 addressed conflicts between Britain and France 
in America, including fishing rights, fur and Indian trade, and illegal smuggling. 
Pair 2 is incorrect 
• After hostilities broke out between the Mughals and the English, Hooghly was sacked by the Mughals 
in October 1686.  
• The English retaliated by capturing the imperial forts at Thana (modern Garden Reach), raiding Hijli in 
east Midnapur, and storming the Mughal fortifications at Balasore.  
• But they were forced to leave Hooghly, and Job Charnock, a company agent, negotiated with the Mughals 
to return to a place called Sutanuti.  
• Charnock signed the treaty of Sutanuti with the Mughals in February 1690 and returned to Sutanuti in 
August 1690.  
• Thus, an English factory was established in February 1691, and  
• An imperial farman was issued permitting the English to "continue contentedly their trade in Bengal" on 
payment of Rs 3,000 a year in lieu of all dues. 
Pair 3 is correct 
• The Dutch captured Pondicherry in 1693 by alliance with the English since the Revolution of 1688.  
• The Treaty of Ryswick restored Pondicherry to the French in September 1697, but the Dutch garrison 
held on to it for two more years. 
• It was a series of treaties signed in the Dutch city of Rijswijk between 20 September and 30 October 1697.  
• They ended the 1688 to 1697 Nine Years' War between France and the Grand Alliance, which included 
the Dutch Republic and the Holy Roman Empire.

questions.question:
How many of the following was a cause for the English success over the French 
in India: 
1. The English company was a public enterprise 
2. English held Calcutta, Bombay, and Puducherry (Pondicherry). 
3. The superiority of commanders in the British camp. 
Select the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect 
• The English company was a private enterprise. 
• It had less governmental control and thus could make instant decisions when needed without waiting 
for the government's approval.  
• The French Company was state-owned and was controlled and regulated by the French government. 
• Government policies hemmed it in, and thus, decision-making was delayed. 
Statement 2 is incorrect 
• The English held three important places: Calcutta, Bombay, and Madras. 
• The French had only Pondicherry. 
Statement 3 is correct 
• It was a significant factor in the success of the English in India. 
• English had a long list of leaders like Sir Eyre Coote, Major Stringer Lawrence, Robert Clive, and many 
others 
• There was only Dupleix on the French side, who could dominate the British. 
• Further, they subordinated their commercial interest to territorial ambition, which made the French Com
pany short of funds.

questions.question: The Battle of Colachel was fought between which of the following powers?

options.text: The Kingdom of Travancore and the Dutch
The kingdom of Travancore and the Portuguese

questions.explanation:
• In August 1741, the Indian kingdom of Travancore clashed with the Dutch East India Company in a 
battle known as the Battle of Colachel (or Kolachel).  
• King Marthanda Varma's army won this battle. 
• His army was led by the commander Anantha Padmanabhan Pillai on land and supported by the brave 
Travancore Nair brigade at sea. 
• This defeat was so significant that the Dutch never regained their colonial power in India. 
• The battle is celebrated as the first victory of Asians over the Europeans.

questions.question:
Which of the following Indian rulers was the first to sign the Subsidiary Alliance 
treaty with the British?
questions.explanation:
• The Subsidiary Alliance was a strategy employed by the British to extend their influence and control 
over the Indian subcontinent gradually. 
• This caused a loss of sovereignty for the Indian princely states. 
• Lord Wellesley developed and implemented the system in 1798. 
• It was based on the ideas of the French Governor-General Joseph Dupleix, who had earlier introduced 
similar treaties in the Carnatic region of southern India. 
• The Subsidiary Alliance effectively reduced Indian rulers to puppet monarchs. 
• Some of the key features of the alliance were: 
 The Indian ruler signing the treaty had to maintain a British-trained army in his territory. 
 The Indian ruler had to accept a British Resident at his court to advise him on political and adminis
trative matters. 
 The Indian ruler had to give up his foreign policy to the British. 
 The Indian ruler had to pay for the maintenance of the British-trained army, which became a heavy 
burden for many rulers. 
• The Nizam of Hyderabad was the first Indian ruler to sign the Subsidiary Alliance treaty with the 
British in 1798.  
• Under this treaty, the Nizam had to maintain a British-trained army and pay a subsidy to the British for 
maintaining this army.

questions.question:
Consider the statements regarding Mir Jafar, who betrayed Nawab Siraj-ud
Daulah at the Battle of Plassey:  
1. The British promised him the throne of Bengal in return for his betrayal. 
2. He fled to Murshidabad after the defeat of the Nawab's army. 
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct 
• Robert Clive convinced Mir Jafar to betray the Nawab by promising him the throne of Bengal in return 
for his help defeating Siraj-ud-Daulah. 
• Mir Jafar saw an opportunity to become the Nawab himself, so he agreed to the British plan. 
• This agreement ensured that the Nawab's army would be weakened by the defection of a critical general 
and his troops. 
Statement 2 is incorrect 
• After the defeat of Nawab Siraj-ud-Daulah at the Battle of Plassey, Mir Jafar did not flee to Murshidabad.  
• Instead, he remained on the battlefield and was crowned the new Nawab of Bengal by Robert Clive as 
promised. 
• Mir Jafar ruled Bengal from 1757 to 1760. 
• Then, he was deposed by the British East India Company for failing to meet their increased revenue de
mands and his involvement in a plot against them.

questions.question:
The introduction of the "dual government" policy in Bengal is one of the signif
icant outcomes of the Battle of Buxar. This policy involved the joint rule of Bengal 
by which of the following powers?

options.text: The British East India Company and the Nawab of Bengal.
The Mughal Emperor and the British East India Company.
The British Governor-General and the Nawab of Bengal.
The British East India Company and the British Crown

questions.explanation:
• Battle of Buxar was fought on October, 1764, between the British East India Company and the com
bined armies of the Nawab of Bengal, Nawab of Awadh, and Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II. 
• The battle took place in the Indian State of Bihar and was a decisive victory for the British. 
• After the Battle of Buxar, the British were firmly established in Bengal. 
• The Treaty of Allahabad was signed on August, 1765, cementing the Company's influence and rule in 
the region. 
• The system of Dual Government was introduced through this treaty. 
• Under Dual government, the administration was divided into two: 
1. Diwani 
 The Company assumed responsibility for collecting land revenues in Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa, 
which gave the Company immense power over the region's economic resources. 
2. Nizamat 
 Carried out by Nizam. 
 He was entrusted with general administration, ensuring law and order, and dispensing justice, 
particularly in criminal cases. 
• Nawab's powers were limited and subject to the Company's approval, effectively reducing his role to a 
figurehead. 
• This system allowed the British to exercise increasing influence over the region, eventually leading to 
complete control and the establishment of the British Raj in India.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding Rani Velu Nachiyar: 
1. She is also known as Veeramangai (the brave one). 
2. She has done the first-ever instance of suicide bombing in India. 
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct 
• Rani Velu Nachiyar was the Queen of Sivagangai estate (Tamil Nadu).  
• She is known by Tamils as Veeramangai (the brave one). 
• After Rani’s husband died in a battle against the combined forces of EIC and the son of the Nawab of 
Arcot, she escaped with her daughter.   
• Rani lived under Haider Ali's protection near Dindigul for eight years and established the first army of 
trained women soldiers. 
• In 1780, Rani waged a war against the British in collaboration with Haider Ali and Gopala Nayaker and 
emerged victorious. 
Statement 2 is correct 
• When Velu Nachiyar found the place where the Company stored some of their ammunition, she arranged 
a suicide attack on the location, blowing it up.   
• This was the first-ever instance of suicide bombing in India.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements: 
1. This particular policy was introduced by Warren Hastings in 1765. 
2. The basic principle of this policy was to defend the Company's territory at the expense of the neigh
bouring state. 
3. It included creating buffer zones to defend the Company’s frontiers. 
Which one of the following policies matches the above statements?
questions.explanation:
• Warren Hasting's Ring Fence Policy is a system designed by the company to protect their territories 
by defending their neighbour’s border at the neighbour’s expense.  
• The basic principle of the Ring Fence Policy was to defend the Company's territory at the expense of the 
neighbouring state. 
• This policy was reflected in Warren Hastings’ wars against the Marathas and Mysore, and aimed at 
creating buffer zones to defend the Company’s frontiers.  
• The main threat was from the Marathas and Afghan invaders (the Company undertook to organise 
Awadh’s defence to safeguard Bengal’s security).

questions.question:
Who was the Sikh ruler who negotiated and signed the Treaty of Amritsar with 
the British in 1809, establishing a favourable relationship between the Sikh Empire 
and the British East India Company?
questions.explanation:
• The Treaty of Amritsar was a significant milestone in the history of British-Sikh relations.  
• Signed in 1809, the treaty established an alliance between the Sikh Empire and the British East India 
Company. 
• Maharaja Ranjit Singh, also known as "Sher-e-Punjab," was the founder and first Maharaja of the Sikh 
Empire.  
• Under his rule, the Sikh Empire established itself as a formidable power in the northwestern region of the 
Indian subcontinent, encompassing modern-day India and Pakistan.  
• The Treaty of Amritsar helped Maharaja Ranjit Singh consolidate his power and expand his empire by 
preventing potential conflicts with the British.  
• In exchange, the British secured access to Punjab's resources and a friendly buffer state between them 
and the Maratha Confederacy and the Durrani Empire.

questions.question:
Consider the following pairs:  
Policy 
1. Policy of Proud Reserve 
Viceroy 
2. Policy of Masterly Inactivity Lytton 
3. Doctrine of Lapse 
John Lawrence 
Dalhousie 
Which of the above pairs are not correctly matched?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is incorrect  
• Lytton became the Viceroy of India in 1876.  
• He started a new foreign policy of ‘proud reserve’, which was aimed at having scientific frontiers and 
safeguarding ‘spheres of influence’.  
• According to Lytton, the relations with Afghanistan could no longer be left ambiguous. 
• The critical elements of the Policy of Proud Reserve include: 
 Building up British military presence in the frontier provinces of Afghanistan to deter Russian expan
sionism. 
 Establishing close relations with the Amir of Afghanistan, Abdur Rahman Khan, to secure British influ
ence in the region. 
Pair 2 is incorrect 
• John Lawrence, the Governor-General of India (1864-69), advocated the Policy of Masterly Inactivity. 
• The Policy of Masterly Inactivity aimed to reach a diplomatic understanding with Russia and adopt a 
policy of watchful non-intervention in Afghanistan.  
• In the case of the Russian attack, the Government of India preferred to meet the danger on the Indian 
frontier itself since it was dangerous to strive for political domination over Afghanistan.  
• The Policy of masterly inactivity arose out of disillusionment with the expense of forward policies, em
phasising observation, consolidation, and negotiation to establish British influence.  
• The Liberals of Britain generally supported the Policy of Masterly Inactivity. 
Pair 3 is correct 
• The Doctrine of Lapse was a controversial policy followed by Dalhousie. 
• According to the Doctrine of Lapse, when the ruler of a protected state died without a natural heir 
(son), his kingdom would lapse, that is, become part of the company’s territory.  
• The state would pass to an adopted child only if the British authorities approved the adoption.  
• That is, the adopted children had no legal right over the throne. 
• Satara became the first state to be annexed under this policy by Dalhousie in 1848. Appa Sahib, the 
king of Satara, died without a natural heir (son) in 1848. Just before death, he had adopted a child but 
did not seek permission from the company.

questions.question: Which of the following treaties was not signed during the Anglo-Mysore Wars?
questions.explanation:
The Treaty of Gwalior is not signed during the Anglo-Mysore Wars 
• Third Anglo-Maratha War (1817-19): 
 Some important treaties were signed. These were:  
 June 1817, Treaty of Poona, with Peshwa.  
 November 1817, Treaty of Gwalior, with Sindhia.  
 January 1818, Treaty of Mandasor, with Holkar.  
• In June 1818, the Peshwa finally surrendered and the Maratha confederacy was dissolved.  
• The peshwaship was abolished.  
• Peshwa Bajirao became a British retainer at Bithur near Kanpur.  
• Pratap Singh, a lineal descendant of Shivaji, was made ruler of a small principality, Satara, formed out of 
the Peshwa’s dominions. 
The Treaty of Madras is related to the Anglo-Mysore Wars 
• The Treaty of Madras brought an end to the First Anglo-Mysore War (1767-69) between the Kingdom 
of Mysore and the British East India Company. 
• It was a peace agreement signed in April 1769 that provided for exchanging prisoners and the conquered 
areas. 
• By treaty, Haidar Ali and the British agreed to help each other in case of an attack by a third party. 
• However, when the Marathas attacked Haidar Ali in 1771, the English did not come to his aid. 
The Treaty of Mangalore is related to the Anglo-Mysore Wars 
• The Treaty of Mangalore was signed in 1784 at the end of the Second Anglo-Mysore War (1780-84). 
• According to the treaty, both parties agreed to restore conquered territories and release the prisoners of 
war. 
The Treaty of Srirangapatnam is related to the Anglo-Mysore Wars 
• The Treaty of Srirangapatnam was signed in 1792 after the Third Anglo-Mysore War (1789-92).  
• By the Treaty of Seringapatam: 
 Tipu ceded half of his territories to the British and their allies.  
 Tipu Paid 330 lakhs of rupees as an indemnity.  
 Tipu’s two sons were taken as hostages by the English till he paid the war indemnity. 
 Both sides agreed to release the prisoners of war

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about Dalhousie: 
1. He served as governor-general of India from 1856-1864. 
2. He made the first attempt towards railway construction in India. 
3. Dalhousie annexed eight states during his eight-year tenure as governor-general. 
4. The last major expansion of British Indian territory took place during his tenure. 
How many of the statements given above are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is Incorrect  
• Dalhousie was the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856.  
• He was determined to extend direct British rule over a vast area.  
• He used the Policy of Doctrine of Lapse to annex Indian princely states. 
Statement 2 is correct 
• The first attempt towards railway construction in India was made by Dalhousie in 1853 AD. 
• He was an ardent advocate of rapid railway construction.  
• He proposed building four major railway lines that would connect the country's interior with the big 
ports and interlink different parts of the nation.  
• In India, the first railway line from Bombay to Thana was opened to traffic in 1853. 
Statement 3 is correct 
• He introduced the system of Doctrine of Lapse. 
• It was a matter of chance that during Lord Dalhousie's term, many rulers of states died without a male 
issue, and seven states were annexed under the Doctrine of Lapse. 
• Satara (1848), Jhansi, and Nagpur (1854) were the most important. 
• The other small states included Jaitapur (Bundelkhand), Sambalpur (Orissa), and Baghat (Madhya 
Pradesh). 
• Lord Dalhousie annexed Awadh in 1856 after deposing Nawab Wajid Ali Shah on grounds of misgov
ernment. 
• Thus, Dalhousie annexed eight states during his eight-year tenure (1848-56) as governor-general. 
Statement 4 is correct 
• The last major expansion of British Indian territory took places during Dalhousie.

questions.question:
Regarding the history of modern India, consider the following statements about 
Warren Hastings: 
1. He was the first Governor-General of Bengal.  
2. The First Anglo-Maratha War and the Second Anglo-Mysore War occurred during his reign. 
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Both statements are correct  
• Warren Hastings was the first Governor-General of Bengal (1772-1785). 
• Military conflicts like the First Anglo-Maratha War and Second Anglo-Mysore War occurred during 
his reign. 
• The first Anglo-Maratha war was fought between 1775 and 1782 and Second Anglo-Mysore war took 
place between 1780 and 1784. 
• Hastings abolished the Dual System that Robert Clive had established. 
• In the Dual System, the Company had Diwani rights (rights to collect revenue) and the Nizam or Indian 
chiefs had the administrative authority.   
• The Regulating Act of 1773 marked a shift in governance, centralising control under Bengal.  
• Administrative, judicial, revenue and social reforms transformed colonial India. 
• The creation of the Supreme Court in 1774, revenue control by the Company, and judicial changes were 
pivotal.

questions.question:
Who among the following was the Governor-General of India/Viceroy at the
time of withdrawal of Doctrine of Lapse?
questions.explanation:
Canning:
 He served as Governor-General of India/Viceroy from 1856 to 1862.
 Lord Canning also served as the first Viceroy of India.
 During his tenure "Doctrine of Lapse" was withdrawn.
 In his tenure, the Government of India Act, of 1858 was passed.
 In that Act, the office of Viceroy was to be held by the same person who was Governor-General of
India.

questions.question:
Regarding the reforms of William Bentinck, consider the following statements:
1. In 1835, he announced the abolition of Persian as the court language and replaced it with English.
2. He set up Sadar Diwani Adalat and Sadar Nizamat Adalat at Allahabad.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
• William Bentinck was appointed the Governor of Madras in 1803.
• From 1828 until 1835, he was the Governor-General of Bengal (1828-1833) and Governor-General of
India (1833-1835).
Statement 1 is correct
• In 1835, William Bentinck announced the abolition of Persian as the court language and replaced it
with English.
• In 1837, English replaced Persian as the language used for administration and higher law courts in Bengal.
• In 1837, English replaced Persian as the official language of the Government.
Statement 2 is correct
• During his tenure, the four Circuit Courts were abolished and their functions transferred to collectors
under the supervision of the commissioner of revenue and circuit.
• Sadar Diwani Adalat and a Sadar Nizamat Adalat were set up at Allahabad for the convenience of the
people of Upper Provinces.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
1. William Bentinck laid the foundation of the Civil Services in India.
2. Robert Clive introduced the Dual government system in India.
3. Lord Dalhousie established Fort William College at Calcutta in 1800.
How many of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• Warren Hastings laid the foundation of the Civil Services in India.
• It was reformed, modernised and rationalised by Cornwallis.
• Hence, Charles Cornwallis is 'the father of civil service in India'.
• In 1786, Cornwallis arrived in India as the Governor-General and attempted to reform the administration.Statement 2 is correct
• Robert Clive, who became the governor of Bengal in 1765, introduced the dual system of government,
i.e. the rule of the two, the Company and the Nawab.
• Under the dual government system:
 As the Diwan, the Company directly collected its revenues.
 Through the right to nominate the Deputy Subahdar (Deputy Nazim), the Company controlled
the Nizamat.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• In 1800, Wellesley (governor-general, 1798-1805) set up the Fort William College for training of new
recruits.
• In 1806 Wellesley’s college was disapproved by the Court of Directors and instead the East India College
was set up at Haileybury in England to impart two years’ training to the recruits.

questions.question:
Which of the following happened during the reign of Lord Canning as the Governor-General?
1. Woods' Despatch
2. Outbreak of Revolt of 1857.
3. First Railway Service in India.
4. Establishment of first three modern Universities in Bombay, Calcutta and Madras.
Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
questions.explanation:
Options 2 and 4 are correct
• Lord Canning served as the Governor-General of India/Viceroy from 1856 to 1862.
• The important events during his tenure include the Outbreak of Revolt of 1857, which he was able to
suppress successfully.
• Under Lord Canning, three universities were set up at Calcutta, Bombay and Madras on the model of
London University.
• The Hindu Widows' Remarriage Act of 1856 was passed.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about Lord Metcalfe:
1. He repealed the Licensing Regulation of 1823.
2. He established the telegraph system and introduced postage stamps.
Which of the statements given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• In 1835, Charles Metcalfe, the acting governor-general, with the help of Thomas Macaulay, repealed
the licensing regulations of 1823 and introduced the Press Act of 1835, also known as the Metcalfe
Act.
• The Metcalfe Act only required a newspaper to declare the address of the printer and the publication.
• This earned Metcalfe the epithet of 'Liberator of the Indian Press'.
• Due to the liberal policy adopted by the Metcalfe, the newspaper rapidly grew.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• Lord Dalhousie established the telegraph system and introduced postage stamps

questions.question:
Consider the following pairs of Viceroys/Governors-General and their Policies:
 Viceroy Importance
1. Lord Hastings Treaty of "Perpetual Friendship"
2. William Bentinck The policy of Intervention and War
3. Lord Cornwallis Permanent settlement of Bengal
How many of the pairs given above are not correctly matched?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is incorrect
• William Bentinck served as the last Governor-General of Bengal from 1828 to 1833 and the inaugural
Governor-General of India from 1833 to 1835.
• He is also called the Father of Modern Western Education in India.
• The annexation of Mysore took place in 1831 during his tenure.
• He negotiated a Treaty of Perpetual Friendship with Ranjit Singh in 1831.
• During his tenure, the Company passed the Charter Act of 1833.
• It stated that Indians should not be debarred from holding any place, office and employment under the
company.
Pair 2 is incorrect
• Lord Hastings served as Governor General of India from 1813 to 1823, a long ten-year term.
• His tenure is known for the Policy of Intervention and War.
• Two important wars viz. Anglo-Nepal War (1814-16) and the Third Anglo-Maratha War occurred during his tenure.
• He simplified the judicial proceedings and abolished the Censorship Act.
Pair 3 is correct
• In 1793, the Governor-General Lord Cornwallis of the East India Company implemented the Permanent
Settlement of Bengal.
• First enacted in Bengal, Bihar and Odisha, this was later followed in northern Madras Presidency and the
district of Varanasi.
• The Permanent Settlement was designed by John Shore, the Governor-General of Bengal (1793-
1798), while he was serving as the revenue official during the Governor-Generalship of Lord Cornwallis.
• The system aimed to set a fixed land revenue based on agricultural productivity.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the Sanyasi Revolt:
1. The revolt was directed against Zamindars and not the British.
2. Anandmath, a novel, is based on the Sanyasi Revolt.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• The Sanyasi Rebellion was a series of conflicts in the late 18th century between the English East India
Company and a group of sannyasis and fakirs.
• Although the then Governor General Warren Hastings (1773-85) was able to control the Sanyasi raids,
the uprisings continued until 1800.
• The establishment of British rule in Bengal after 1757 resulted in devastating conditions for zamindars,
peasants, and artisans due to the economic policies enforced.
• In 1770, Bengal experienced a severe famine.
• Despite this, the British continued to collect taxes.
• The British government thought that Sannyasis were plunderers and thugs and imposed restrictions
on visiting holy places. The sannyasis were enraged by the British's brutal policy and resolved to protest.
• The growing hardship of the peasantry, increasing revenue demand, and the Bengal famine of 1770
brought many dispossessed small Zamindars, disbanded soldiers and rural poor into the bands of Sanyasis and Fakirs.
• Nomadic Sanyasis and Fakirs in northern Bengal attacked food stores, the property of the local richmen
and government officials.
• They looted government treasuries and sometimes shared the wealth with the poor.
• Some of the important leaders of these movements were Manju Shah, Musa Shah, Bhawani Pathak,
and Debi Chaudhurani.
• There was equal participation of Hindus and Muslims, who unitedly defeated the British several times.
• To control the Sanyasi raids, the then Governor-General Warren Hastings (1773-85) issued a proclamation
banishing all sannyasis from Bengal and Bihar. Statement 2 is correct
• 'Anandmath,' a semi-historical novel by Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay, is based on the Sanyasi Revolt.
• Bankim Chandra also wrote a novel, 'Devi Chaudhurani,' as he saw the importance of women taking up
the struggle against an alien rule that threatened traditional Indian values.

questions.question:
Consider the following pairs:
Revolt Present-day Location
1. Revolt of Moamarias Kerala
2. Revolt of Raja of Vizianagaram Uttar Pradesh
3. Kuka Movement Manipur
How many of the above pairs is/are not correctly matched?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is incorrectly matched
• Revolt of Moamarias (1769-99)
 The revolt of the Moamarias in 1769 was a potent challenge to the authority of the Ahom kings of
Assam.
 The Moamarias were low-caste peasants who followed the teachings of Aniruddhadeva (1553-
1624), and their rise was similar to that of other low-caste groups in north India.
 Their revolts weakened the Ahoms and opened the doors for others to attack the region; for instance, in 1792, the King of Darrang (Krishnanarayan), assisted by his band of burkandazes (the
demobilised soldiers of the Muslim armies and zamindars) revolted.
 The Ahom ruler had to request British help to crush these revolts.
 The Moamarias made Bhatiapar their headquarters.
 Rangpur (now in Bangladesh) and Jorhat were the regions most affected.
 Although the Ahom kingdom survived the rebellion, the weakened kingdom fell to a Burmese invasion and finally came under British rule.
Pair 2 is incorrectly matched
• Revolt of Raja of Vizianagaram (1794)
 In 1758, a treaty was made between the English and Ananda Gajapatiraju, the ruler of Vizianagaram (modern-day Andhra Pradesh), to jointly oust the French from the Northern Circars.
 In this mission, they were successful, but the English, as usual in their case in India, went back on their
word to honour the treaty's terms.
 Anand Raju died before he could tackle the English seriously. The East India Company demanded a
tribute of three lakh rupees from Vizayaramaraju, the Raja of Vizianagaram, and asked him to disband
his troops.
 This angered the Raja as there were no dues to be paid to the Company.
 The Raja, supported by his subjects, rose in revolt. The English captured the Raja in 1793 and ordered
him to go into exile with a pension. The Raja refused.
 The Raja died in a battle at Padmanabham (in modern Visakhapatnam district in Andhra Pradesh)
1794. Vizianagaram came under the Company’s rule.
 Later, the Company offered the estate to the deceased Raja's son and reduced the demand for presents.
Pair 3 is incorrectly matched
• Kuka Movement
 The Kuka Movement was founded in 1840 by Bhagat Jawahar Mal (also called Sian Saheb) in
western Punjab.
 A prominent leader of the movement after him was Baba Ram Singh. (He founded the Namdhari
Sikh sect.)
 After the British took Punjab, the movement transformed from a religious purification campaign to
a political campaign.
 Its basic tenets were:
• Abolition of caste and similar discriminations among Sikhs
• Discouraging the consumption of meat, alcohol, and drugs
• Permission for intermarriages, widow remarriage, and encouraging women to step out of seclusion.
 On the political side, the Kukas wanted to remove the British and restore Sikh rule over Punjab.
 They advocated wearing hand-woven clothes and boycott of English laws and education and products.
 The concepts of Swadeshi and non-cooperation were propagated by the Kukas, even before the
Swadeshi Movement.
 As the movement gained popularity, the British took several steps to crush it between 1863 and 1872.
 In 1872, Ram Singh was deported to Rangoon.

questions.question:
How many of the following is/are the cause(s) for civil uprisings before 1857?
1. Changes in the land revenue system
2. Ruin of Indian handicraft industries
3. Indigenous character of British rulers
Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
questions.explanation:
Option 1 and 2 are correct, but option 3 is incorrect
• The causes of uprisings before 1857 are:
 Under the Company rule, rapid changes in the economy, administration, and land revenue system
went against the people.
 Several zamindars and poligars who had lost control over their land and its revenues due to the
colonial rule had personal scores to settle with the new rulers.
 The ego of traditional zamindars and poligars was hurt due to being sidelined in rank by government
officials and a new class comprising merchants and moneylenders.
 The ruin of Indian handicraft industries due to colonial policies impoverished millions of artisans
whose misery was further compounded by the disappearance of their traditional patrons and buyers—princes, chieftains, and zamindars.
 The priestly classes instigated hatred and rebellion against alien rule because the religious preachers,
priests, pundits, maulvis, etc., had been dependent on the traditional landed and bureaucratic elite.
The fall of zamindars and feudal lords directly affected the priestly class.
 The foreign character of the British rulers, who always remained alien to this land, and their contemptuous treatment of the native people hurt the latter's pride.

questions.question: ‘Kundara proclamation’ is related to which among the following?
questions.explanation:
Option (c) is correct
• Diwan Velu Thampi's Revolt (1808-1809):
 The East India Company's harsh conditions imposed on the state of Travancore after both agreed to
a subsidiary alliance arrangement under Wellesley in 1805 caused deep resentment in the region.
 The ruler was not able to pay the subsidy and fell in arrears.
 The British resident of Travancore was meddling in the state's internal affairs.
 The high-handed attitude of the Company compelled Prime Minister (or Dalawa) Velu Thampi to
rise against the Company, assisted by the Nair troops.
 Velu Thampi addressed a gathering in Kundara, openly calling for arms to be taken against the
British to oust them from the native soil. This was later known as the Kundara Proclamation.
 There was a large-scale rebellion against the British as a result.
 A large military operation had to be undertaken to restore peace.
 The Maharaja of Travancore had not wholly supported the rebellion and defected to the side of the
Company.
 Velu Thampi killed himself to avoid capture. The rebellion petered out.
Option (a) is incorrect
• Paika Rebellion (1817):
 The Paiks of Odisha were the traditional landed militia ('foot soldiers' literally) and enjoyed rentfree land tenures for their military service and policing functions on a hereditary basis.
 The English Company's conquest of Odisha in 1803 and the dethronement of the Raja of Khurda
had significantly reduced the power and prestige of the Paiks.
 Further, the extortionist land revenue policy of the Company caused resentment among zamindars
and peasants alike.
 Common masses were affected by the rise in salt prices due to taxes imposed on it, the abolition
of cowrie currency, the requirement to pay taxes in silver, etc.
 Bakshi Jagabandhu Bidyadhar had been the military chief of the forces of the Raja of Khurda. In
1814, the Company took Jagabandhu's ancestral estate of Killa Rorang, reducing him to poverty.
 With the active support of Mukunda Deva, the last Raja of Khurda, and other zamindars of the region,
Bakshi Jagabandhu Bidyadhar led a sundry army of Paikas, forcing the East India Company forces to
retreat for a time.
 The rebellion came to be known as the Paika Bidroh (rebellion).
Option (b) is incorrect
● Khasi Uprising (Tribal Uprising):
 After occupying the hilly region between Garo and Jaintia Hills, the East India Company wanted to
build a road linking the Brahmaputra Valley with Sylhet.
 For this, many outsiders, including Englishmen, Bengalis and labourers from the plains, were brought
to these regions.
 The Khasis, Garos, Khamptis and Singphos organised themselves under Tirath Singh to drive away
the strangers from the plains.
 The uprising developed into a popular revolt against British rule in the area.
 By 1833, the superior English military force had suppressed the revolt.
Option (d) is incorrect
● Narkelberi Uprising:
 Mir Nithar Ali (1782-1831), or Titu Mir, inspired the Muslim tenants in West Bengal to rise against
landlords, mainly Hindu, who imposed a beard tax on the Faraizis and British indigo planters.
 Often considered the first armed peasant uprising against the British, this revolt soon took on a
religious hue.
 The revolt later merged into the Wahabi movement.

questions.question: Which of the following uprising is called 'Revolt of Jungle Mahal'?
questions.explanation:
Option (c) is correct
• Chuar Uprising (1766-1772 & 1795-1816):
 The term 'Chuar' is considered derogatory by some historians who call this the Revolt of the Jungle
Mahal, instead.
 Famine, enhanced land revenue demands, and economic distress goaded the Chuar aboriginal tribesmen of the Jungle Mahal of the Midnapore district and the Bankura district (in Bengal) to take up
arms.
 These tribes' people were basically farmers and hunters.
 The uprising lasted from 1766 to 1772 and surfaced between 1795 and 1816.
 The Chuars were prominent in Manbhum and Barabhum, especially in the hills between Barabhum
and Ghatsila.
 They held their lands under a kind of feudal tenure, but were not strongly attached to the soil,
being always ready to change from farming to hunting, at the bidding of their jungle chiefs or zamindars.
 In 1768, Jagannath Singh, the zamindar of Ghatsila, went up in arms, alongwith thousands of Chuars.
The Company government capitulated.
 In 1771, the Chuar sardars, Shyam Ganjan of Dhadka, Subla Singh of Kaliapal and Dubraj rose in
rebellion. This time, however, they were suppressed.
 The most significant uprising was under Durjan (or Durjol) Singh in 1798. Durjan Singh was the
zamindar of Raipur from which he was dispossessed owing to the operations of Bengal Regulations.
 In May 1798, his followers, a body of 1,500 Chuars, indulged in violent activities in Raipur to halt the
auction of the estate of Raipur.
 The revolt was brutally suppressed by the British.
 Other leaders of the Chuars were Madhab Singh, the brother of the Raja of Barabhum, Raja Mohan
Singh, zamindar of Juriah and Lachman Singh of Dulma.
Option (a) is incorrect
• Ho and Munda Uprising (1820-1837)
 The Raja of Parahat organised his Ho tribals to revolt against the occupation of Singhbhum (now
in Jharkhand).
 The revolt continued till 1827 when the Ho tribals were forced to submit.
 However, later in 1831, they again organised a rebellion, joined by the Mundas of Chotanagpur, to
protest the newly introduced farming revenue policy and the entry of Bengalis into their region.
 Though the revolt was extinguished in 1832, the Ho operations continued till 1837.
 Nor were the Mundas to be quiet for long. [In 1899-1900, the Mundas in the region south of Ranchi
rose under Birsa Munda].
 The Ulgulan was one of the most significant tribal uprisings in the period 1860-1920.
 The rebellion which began as a religious movement gathered political force to fight against introduction of feudal, zamindari tenures, and exploitation by moneylenders and forest contractors.
 The Mundas claimed Chhotanagpur as their area in 1879. British armed forces were then deployed.
Birsa was captured and imprisoned.
Option (b) is incorrect
• Kol Mutiny (1831):
 The Kols, alongwith other tribes, are inhabitants of Chhotanagpur.
 This covered Ranchi, Singhbhum, Hazaribagh, Palamau and the western parts of Manbhum.
 The trouble in 1831 started with large-scale transfers of land from Kol headmen to outsiders like
Hindu, Sikh and Muslim farmers and moneylenders who were oppressive and demanded heavy taxes.
 Besides, the British judicial and revenue policies badly affected the traditional social conditions of the
Kols.
 The Kols resented this and in 1831, under the leadership of Buddho Bhagat, the Kol rebels killed or
burnt about a thousand outsiders. Only after large-scale military operations could order be restored.
Option (d) is incorrect
• Santhal Rebellion (1855-56):
 Continued oppression of the Santhals, an agricultural people, who had fled to settle in the plains of
the Rajmahal hills (Bihar) led to the Santhal rebellion against the zamindars.
 The moneylenders who had the support of the police among others had joined the zamindars to
subject the peasants to oppressive exactions and dispossession of lands.
 The rebellion turned into an anti-British movement.
 Under Sidhu and Kanhu, two brothers, the Santhals proclaimed an end to Company rule, and declared the area between Bhagalpur and Rajmahal as autonomous.
 The rebellion was suppressed by 1856.

questions.question:
Consider the following information:
 Uprising Place Leader

2. Ramosi Rising Western Ghats Chittur Singh

In how many of the above rows is/are the given information correctly matched?

• Koya Revolt:
 The Koyas of the eastern Godavari track (modern Andhra), joined by Khonda Sara chiefs, rebelled
in 1803, 1840, 1845, 1858, 1861 and 1862.

customary rights over forest areas.
 After the death of Tomma Sora, another rebellion was organised in 1886 by Raja Anantayyar.

• Ramosi Rising:
 The Ramosis, the hill tribes of the Western Ghats, had not reconciled to British rule and the British
pattern of administration.
 They resented the policy of annexation.

 Again, there were eruptions in 1825-26 under Umaji Naik of Poona and his supporter Bapu Trimbakji

organise revolts.
 An uprising in 1839 saw the death of the British political agent.
 Chief Nirang Phidu led an uprising in 1843, which involved an attack on the British garrison and the
death of many soldiers.

questions.question: Which of the following began as Sanskritization movement?
questions.explanation:

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
1. Statement-I: Barrackpore mutiny erupted in 1824, led by Bindee Tiwary.
2. Statement-II: The sepoys refused to board boats to cross the sea to Burma in the First Anglo Burmese
War.
Which one of the following is correct in respect of the above statements?

options.text: Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is the correct explanation for Statement-I.

Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is not the correct explanation for
Statement-I.
Statement-I is correct but Statement-II is incorrect.
Statement-I is incorrect but Statement-II is correct.

questions.explanation:
The Barrackpore Mutiny took place during the First Anglo-Burmese War (1824-1826).
• The British East India Company was engaged in expanding its territories, and this war was part of their
efforts against the Burmese Empire.
• The mutiny occurred at the Barrackpore cantonment near Calcutta (now Kolkata).
• Indian sepoys (soldiers) of the British East India Company's Bengal Army rebelled against their British
officers.
• Bindee Tiwary was one of the prominent figures leading the mutiny. He was a sepoy who voiced the
grievances of his fellow soldiers.
• The primary cause of the mutiny was the sepoys' refusal to cross the sea (Kala Pani) to fight in Burma.
This refusal was rooted in religious beliefs and social customs, as crossing the sea was believed to lead
to a loss of caste and social status.
• In the early 19th century, many Indian sepoys held strong religious and social beliefs that prohibited
crossing the sea (Kala Pani). They believed that doing so would result in the loss of their caste and make
them social outcasts upon their return.

questions.question:
Which of the following was/were the reason(s) behind the Revolt of 1857?
1. Rampant corruption in the Company's administration.
2. Attempts of socio-religious reforms by the British, such as the abolition of sati.
3. Implementation of the General Service Enlistment Act.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
All three statements are correct
• The causes of the revolt of 1857 emerged from all aspects: socio-cultural, economic, and political.
• Rampant corruption in the Company's administration, especially among the police, petty officials, and
lower law courts was a major cause of discontent.
• Racial overtones and a superiority complex characterised the British administrative attitude towards
the native Indian population.
• The attempts at socio-religious reform, such as the abolition of sati, support for widow-remarriage,
and women's education, were seen by a large section of the population as interference in the social
and religious domains of Indian society by outsiders.
• These fears were compounded by the government's decision to tax mosque and temple lands and make
laws such as the Religious Disabilities Act of 1856, which modified Hindu customs.
• For instance, declaring that a change of religion did not debar a son from inheriting the property of his
'heathen' father.
• Outside events in which the British suffered severe losses, the First Afghan War (1838-42), the Punjab
Wars (1845-49), and the Crimean Wars (1854-56) had obvious psychological repercussions.
• The British were seen to be not so strong, and it was felt that they could be defeated.
• To the religious Hindu of the time, crossing the seas meant the loss of caste. In 1856, Lord Canning's
Government passed the General Service Enlistment Act, which decreed that all future recruits to the
Bengal Army would have to give the undertaking to serve anywhere their services might be required by
the government. This caused resentment among the sepoys.
• A more immediate cause of the sepoys' dissatisfaction was the order that they would not be given the
foreign service allowance (Bhatta) when serving in Sindh or Punjab.
• The annexation of Awadh, home of many of the sepoys, further inflamed their feelings
• The colonial policies of the East India Company destroyed the traditional economic fabric of Indian society.
• New and highly unpopular revenue settlement.
• Impoverished by heavy taxation, the peasants resorted to loans from moneylenders/traders at usurious
rates, the latter often evicting the former from their land on non-payment of debt dues.

questions.question:
Which leaders were involved in the British resistance in Kanpur during the 1857
revolt:
1. Sir Hugh Wheeler
2. Sir Colin Campbell
3. Sir Hugh Rose
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
The revolt began at Meerut, 58 km from Delhi, on May 10, 1857, and then, gathering force rapidly, soon
embraced a vast area from Punjab in the north, the Narmada in the south to Bihar in the east, and Rajputana in the west.
• After prolonged and bitter fighting, the British captured Delhi on September 20, 1857.
• Bahadur Shah was taken prisoner. The royal princes were captured and butchered on the spot, publicly
shot at point-blank range by Lieutenant Hudson himself.
• The emperor was exiled to Rangoon, where he died in 1862; thus, the great House of Mughals was
finally completely extinguished.
• A terrible vengeance was wreaked on the inhabitants of Delhi, and with the fall of Delhi, the focal point
of the revolt disappeared.
• One by one, all the great leaders of the revolt fell.
• Military operations for the recapture of Kanpur were closely associated with Lucknow's recovery.
• Nana Saheb expelled the English from Kanpur, proclaimed himself the peshwa, acknowledged Bahadur
Shah as the Emperor of India and declared himself to be his governor. Sir Hugh Wheeler, commanding
the station, surrendered on June 27, 1857 and was killed on the same day.
• Sir Colin Campbell occupied Kanpur on December 6, 1857. Nana Saheb, defeated at Kanpur, escaped
to Nepal in early 1859, never to be heard again.
• His close associate Tantia Tope escaped into the jungles of central India but was captured while asleep
in April 1859 and put to death.
• The Rani of Jhansi had died on the battlefield earlier in June 1858. Sir Hugh Rose recaptured Jhansi.
• By 1859, Kunwar Singh, Bakht Khan, Khan Bahadur Khan of Bareilly, Rao Sahib (brother of Nana
Saheb), and Maulvi Ahmadullah were all dead, while the Begum of Awadh was compelled to hide in
Nepal.
• At Benaras, a rebellion had been organised, which was mercilessly suppressed by Colonel Neill, who put
to death all suspected rebels and even disorderly sepoys.
• By the end of 1859, British authority over India was fully re-established.
• The British Government had to pour immense supplies of men, money, and arms into the country, though
the Indians had to repay the entire cost through their suppression later.
• The British Resistance
 Delhi - Lieutenant Willoughby, John Nicholson, Lieutenant Hudson
 Kanpur - Sir Hugh Wheeler, Sir Colin Campbell
 Lucknow - Henry Lawrence, Brigadier Inglis, Henry Havelock, James Outram, Sir Colin Campbell
 Jhansi - Sir Hugh Rose
 Benaras - Colonel James Neill

questions.question:
With reference to the Government of India Act 1858, consider the following
statements:
1. The British Parliament passed the Act for the Better Government of India in 1858, even before the
complete suppression of the 1857 Revolt.
2. The dual system introduced by the Pitt's India Act ended through this Act.
3. It has a provision that the Company would continue possessing territories unless the Parliament provided otherwise.
How many of the above statements are correct?
questions.explanation:
The 1857 revolt had exposed the Company's limitations in administering under a complex situation.
• Till then, there had not been much accountability. The 1858 Act sought to rectify this anomaly.
Statement 1 is correct
• The Revolt of 1857 marks a turning point in the history of India.
• It led to far-reaching changes in the system of administration and the policies of the British Government.
• Even before the Revolt could be suppressed entirely, the British Parliament, on August 2, 1858, passed
an Act for the Better Government of India.
• The Act declared Queen Victoria as the sovereign of British India and provided for the appointment
of a Secretary of State for India (a member of the British cabinet).
• The direct responsibility for the administration of the country was assumed by the British Crown, and
Company rule was abolished.
Statement 2 is correct
• India was to be governed by and in the name of the Crown through a secretary of state and a council
of 15.
• The initiative and the final decision were to be made by the Secretary of State, and the council was to be
just advisory.
• Thus, the dual system introduced by the Pitt's India Act came to an end.
• Governor-general became the viceroy (his prestige, if not authority, increased).
• The assumption of power by the Crown was one of formality rather than substance. It gave a decent
burial to an already dead horse - the Company's administration.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• The Charter Act of 1853 provides that the Company was to continue possessing territories unless the
Parliament provided otherwise.
• Through the 1858 Act, company rule was completely abolished, and the Crown took over Indian administration

questions.question: Who served as the Governor General of India during the 1857 revolt?
questions.explanation:
Option (b) is correct
• Lord Canning was the governor-general of India from 1856-1857, during which time the Revolt of 1857
happened.
• After the Revolt of 1857, the assumption of the Government of India by the sovereign of Great Britain
was announced by Lord Canning at a durbar at Allahabad in the 'Queen's Proclamation' issued on November 1, 1858.
• By this proclamation, the governor-general acquired the additional title of 'Viceroy.'
• From 1858-1862, Lord Canning acted as the Viceroy of India.
• Significant developments during his period:
 Three universities were established in Calcutta, Madras, and Bombay in 1857.
 Revolt of 1857.
 Transfer of control from East India Company to the Crown, the Government of India Act, 1858.
 'White Mutiny' by European troops in 1859.
 Indian Councils Act of 1861.
Option (c) is incorrect
• Lord William Bentinck was Governor-General of Bengal (1828-33)and Governor-General of India from
1833-1835.
• Significant developments during his period:
 Abolition of sati and other cruel rites (1829).
 Suppression of thugi (1830).
 Charter Act of 1833.
 Resolution of 1835, educational reforms, and introduction of English as the official language.
 Annexation of Mysore (1831), Coorg (1834), and Central Cachar (1834).
 Treaty of 'perpetual friendship' with Ranjeet Singh.
 Abolition of the provincial courts of appeal and circuit set up by Cornwallis, appointment of commissioners of revenue and circuit.
Option (a) is incorrect
• Lord Dalhousie was the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856.
• Significant developments during his period:
 Second Anglo-Sikh War (1848-49) and annexation of Punjab (1849).
 Annexation of Lower Burma or Pegu (1852).
 Introduction of the Doctrine of Lapse and annexation of Satara (1848), Jaitpur and Sambhalpur
(1849), Udaipur (1852), Jhansi (1853), Nagpur (1854) and Awadh (1856).
 "Wood's (Charles Wood, President of the Board of Control) Educational Despatch" of 1854 and
the opening of Anglo-vernacular schools and government colleges.
 Railway Minute of 1853; and laying down the first railway line connecting Bombay and Thane in
1853.
 Telegraph (4000 miles of telegraph lines to connect Calcutta with Bombay, Madras, and Peshawar)
and postal (Post Office Act, 1854) reforms.
 Ganges Canal was declared open (1854), establishing separate public works departments in every
province.
 Widow Remarriage Act (1856).
Option (d) is incorrect
• Lord Lytton was the viceroy of India from 1876 to 1880.
• Significant developments during his period:
 The famine of 1876-78 affected Madras, Bombay, Mysore, Hyderabad, parts of central India, and
Punjab; appointment of Famine Commission under the presidency of Richard Strachey (1878).
 Royal Titles Act (1876), Queen Victoria assumed the title of 'Kaiser-i-Hind' or Queen Empress of
India.
 The Vernacular Press Act (1878).
 The Arms Act (1878).
 The Second Afghan War (1878-80)

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
1. The Indian Councils Act of 1861 returned the legislative powers to the provinces of Madras and Bombay.
2. Financial decentralisation was a legislative devolution inaugurated by the Indian Councils Act of 1861.
3. The portfolio system introduced by Lord Canning laid the foundations of cabinet government in India.
How many of the above statements are correct?
questions.explanation:
Indian Councils Act, 1861
 The 1861 Act marked an advance in that the principle of representatives of non-officials in legislative bodies became accepted; laws were to be made after due deliberation, and as pieces of legislation, they could be changed only by the same deliberative process.
 Law-making was thus no longer seen as the exclusive business of the executive.
Statement 1 is correct
• The Indian Councils Act of 1861 returned the legislative powers to the provinces of Madras and Bombay, which had been taken away in 1833.
• Later, legislative councils were established in other provinces. The three presidencies of Bombay,
Madras, and Calcutta enjoyed more rights and powers compared to other provinces.
• The presidencies were administrated by a governor and his executive council who were appointed by
the Crown.
• At the same time, other provinces were administered by lieutenant governors and chief commissioners
appointed by the governor-general.
• By vesting legislative powers in the Governments of Bombay and Madras and making provision for the
institution of similar legislative councils in other provinces, the Act laid the foundations of legislative
devolution.
• However, the legislative councils established by the Act of 1861 had no real powers and many weaknesses.
Statement 2 is correct
• Financial decentralisation was a legislative devolution inaugurated by the Indian Councils Act of 1861.
• Apart from the annual grant from the imperial government, the provincial governments were authorised to resort to local taxation to balance their budgets.
• This was done in the context of the transfer of certain departments of administration, such as medical
services, education, and roads, to the control of provincial governments.
• This was the beginning of local finance.
• Mayo's Resolution of 1870 emphasised, "Local interest, supervision, and care are necessary for success
in the management of the funds devoted to education, sanitation, medical relief, and local public works."
• The various provincial governments, such as in Bengal, Madras, North-Western Province, and Punjab,
passed municipal acts to implement the policy outlined.
Statement 3 is correct
• The portfolio system introduced by Lord Canning laid the foundations of cabinet government in
India, with each branch of the administration having its official head and spokesman in the government,
who was responsible for its administration.

questions.question: With reference to the 1857 revolt, which of the following statement is not correct?

options.text: Bahadur Shah was taken as a prisoner and publicly shot at point-blank range by Lieutenant Hudson.
The introduction of the Enfield rifle enhanced the sepoy's growing disaffection with the government.
The Rani of Jhansi had died on the battlefield.
Mangal Pande was the first martyr of the 1857 revolt.

questions.explanation:
Statement (a) is incorrect
• At Delhi, the nominal and symbolic leadership belonged to the Mughal emperor, Bahadur Shah, but the
real command lay with a court of soldiers headed by General Bakht Khan.
• Emperor Bahadur Shah was perhaps the weakest link in the chain of leadership of the revolt. His weak
personality, old age, and lack of leadership qualities created political weakness at the nerve center of the
revolt and did incalculable damage.
• The revolt was finally suppressed. The British captured Delhi on September 20, 1857, after prolonged and
bitter fighting
• Bahadur Shah was taken prisoner. The royal princes were captured and butchered on the spot, publicly
shot at point-blank range by Lieutenant Hudson himself.
• The emperor was exiled to Rangoon, where he died in 1862. Thus, the great House of Mughals was
finally and completely extinguished.
Statement (b) is correct
• The reports about mixing bone dust in atta (flour) and introducing the Enfield rifle enhanced the
sepoys' growing disaffection with the government.
• The greased wrapping paper of the new rifle cartridge had to be bitten off before loading, and the
grease was reportedly made of beef and pig fat.
• The cow was sacred to the Hindus, while the pig was taboo for the Muslims.
• The Army administration did nothing to allay these fears, and the sepoys felt their religion was in grave
danger.
Statement (c) is correct
• The most outstanding leader of the revolt was Rani Laxmibai, who assumed the leadership of the sepoys
at Jhansi.
• Lord Dalhousie, the governor-general, had refused to allow her adopted son to succeed to the throne
after her husband, Raja Gangadhar Rao, died and had annexed the state by applying the infamous'
Doctrine of Lapse'.
• Driven out of Jhansi by British forces, she gave the battle cry -"main apni Jhansi nahin doongi" (I shall
not give away my Jhansi).
• She was joined by Tantia Tope, a close associate of Nana Saheb, after the loss of Kanpur.
• The Rani of Jhansi and Tantia Tope marched towards Gwalior, where the Indian soldiers hailed them.
• However, the Sindhia, the local ruler, decided to side with the English and took shelter at Agra. Nana
Saheb was proclaimed the Peshwa, and plans were made to march into the south. The English recaptured
Gwalior in June 1858.
• The Rani of Jhansi died on the battlefield earlier in June 1858. Sir Hugh Rose recaptured Jhansi.
Statement (d) is correct
• The 19th Native Infantry at Berhampur (West Bengal), which refused to use the newly introduced
Enfield rifle and broke out in mutiny in February 1857, was disbanded in March 1857.
• A young sepoy of the 34th Native Infantry, Mangal Pande, fired at the sergeant major of his unit at
Barrackpore.
• He was overpowered and executed on April 8, while his regiment was disbanded in May.
• The 7th Awadh Regiment, which defied its officers on May 3, met a similar fate.

questions.question:
Who among the following said, "The revolt of 1857 was a last ditch stand of
feudalism against commercial capitalism?"
questions.explanation:
Different views on the nature of the 1857 revolt:
 It was a mere 'Sepoy Mutiny' to some British historians.
 "A wholly unpatriotic and selfish Sepoy Mutiny with no native leadership and no popular support,"
said Sir John Seeley.
 M.N. Roy felt the revolt was a last-ditch stand of feudalism against commercial capitalism.
 V.D. Savarkar in his book, The Indian War of Independence, 1857. Savarkar called the revolt the
first war of Indian independence. He said it was inspired by the lofty ideal of self-rule by Indians
through a nationalist upsurge.
 Dr S.N. Sen, in his book Eighteen Fifty-Seven, considers the revolt as having begun as a fight for
religion but ended as a war of independence.
 Dr. R.C. Majumdar considers it neither the first nor national nor a war of independence as large
parts of the country remained unaffected, and many sections of the people took no part in the upsurge.
 Jawaharlal Nehru considered the Revolt of 1857 as essentially a feudal uprising, although there
were some nationalistic elements in it (Discovery of India).
 R.P. Dutt also saw the significance of the revolt of the peasantry against foreign domination, even
as he acknowledged it to be a defence of the old feudal order

questions.question:

questions.question:
Consider the following events:
1. Establishment of three universities at Calcutta, Madras, and Bombay in 1857.
2. Revolt of 1857.
3. Transfer of control from East India Company to the Crown, the Government of India Act, 1858.
4. 'White Mutiny' by European troops in 1859.
The events described occurred during which Governor General/Viceroy period?
questions.explanation:
Option (d) is correct
• During Lord Canning's tenure (1856-62), several significant events shaped British rule in India.
• In 1857, amidst rising tensions, three universities were established in Calcutta, Madras, and Bombay,
aimed at bolstering colonial education policies.
• This period also witnessed the outbreak of the Revolt of 1857, marking a pivotal moment of resistance
against British rule.
• Following these upheavals, control over India was transferred from the East India Company to the British
Crown under the Government of India Act, 1858, heralding a new era of direct British governance.
• In 1859, European troops staged the 'White Mutiny,' a protest against changes in military service terms,
highlighting simmering discontent within the British Indian Army.
• Additionally, the Indian Councils Act of 1861 was enacted, granting Indians limited legislative powers
and marking a step towards a more inclusive governance framework under British rule.
Option (a) is incorrect
• During Lord Elgin's tenure (1862-1863), one significant development was the Wahabi Movement in
India.
• The movement, originating in Arabia and championed by Indian Muslim scholars, sought to purify and
reform Islam.
• It gained momentum in the early 19th century under leaders like Syed Ahmad Barelvi and Shah Ismail
Dehlvi, who advocated for a return to orthodox Islamic practices and resistance against British influence.
• The movement's adherents, known as Wahabis, were particularly active in the northwest regions of India,
including present-day Pakistan.
• The Wahabis played an important role in spreading anti-British sentiments.
• A series of military operations by the British in the 1860s on the Wahabi base in Sithana and various court
cases of sedition on the Wahabis weakened the Wahabi resistance, although sporadic encounters with
the authorities continued into the 1880s and 1890s.
Option (b) is incorrect
• During Lord Northbrook's tenure (1872-76) as Viceroy of India, several notable events unfolded.
• In 1875, India welcomed the visit of the Prince of Wales, later King Edward VII, which aimed to
strengthen ties between Britain and its Indian subjects.
• Concurrently, Lord Northbrook oversaw the trial of the Gaekwad of Baroda, a significant princely state
ruler accused of misrule and misconduct.
• Additionally, the period witnessed the Kuka Movement in Punjab, a religious and social movement led
by Baba Ram Singh aimed at reforming Sikh society and resisting British colonial policies.
• These events underscored the complexities of governance and the diverse challenges faced during Lord
Northbrook's administration in colonial India.
Option (c) is incorrect
• Lord Elgin II served as Viceroy of India from 1894 to 1899, during which a significant event occurred
with the assassination of two British officials by the Chapekar brothers in 1897.
• The Chapekar brothers, Damodar and Balkrishna, were Indian nationalists who targeted British officials
in Pune, India, as a protest against colonial rule and oppressive policies. The assassination of Rand and Ayerst, two British officers, sparked widespread outrage among British
authorities, leading to a crackdown on Indian nationalist activities and intensifying tensions between Indian nationalists and the British administration.
• This incident highlighted growing Indian discontent and resistance against British rule in the late 19th
century, setting the stage for later nationalist movements and demands for self-rule in India.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding Lord Lansdowne:
1. The Third Burmese War occurred during his period.
2. The Factory Act of 1891 was framed during the viceroyship of Lord Lansdowne.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• The Third Burmese War took place during the tenure of Lord Dufferin, who served as Viceroy of India
from 1884 to 1888.
• This conflict arose due to tensions between the British Empire and the Kingdom of Burma over territorial
disputes and British interests in the region.
• The war concluded with the annexation of Upper Burma by the British Empire in January 1886, marking the end of Burmese sovereignty and the incorporation of Burma into British India as a province.
• The Third Burmese War expanded British influence in Southeast Asia and solidified British control over
Burma, while also contributing to the complexities of imperial governance during Lord Dufferin's viceroyalty.
Statement 2 is correct
• The Factory Act of 1891 was enacted during the viceroyalty of Lord Lansdowne, who served as Viceroy
of India from 1888 to 1894.
• This legislation aimed to regulate the working conditions in factories across British India, addressing concerns over labour rights and industrial safety.
• The act introduced several key provisions, including restrictions on child labour, limitation of working
hours for women and children, and improved safety measures within factory premises.
• It represented a significant step towards protecting the welfare of industrial workers and promoting social
reforms amidst the rapid industrialisation under British colonial rule.

questions.question: The Ilbert Bill controversy is related to:

options.text: The ongoing debate over the legacy of colonial statues and monuments in public spaces.
The controversy surrounding reparations for colonial-era atrocities.
The controversy over the role of colonial education policies.
To allow senior Indian magistrates to preside over cases involving British subjects in India.

questions.explanation:
Option (d) is correct
• The Ilbert Bill controversy occurred during the viceroyship of Lord Ripon (George Robinson), who
served as Viceroy of India from 1880 to 1884.
• The Ilbert Bill controversy centered around proposed legislative reforms concerning the jurisdiction of
Indian judges over European British subjects.
• Introduced by Sir Courtenay Ilbert, the then-legal adviser to the Government of India, the bill sought to
allow Indian judges to preside over cases involving European British subjects in India.
• This proposal sparked vehement opposition from the European community in India, who perceived it as
a threat to their privileged legal status and racial superiority.
• The controversy highlighted deep-seated racial prejudices and colonial hierarchies within the British Raj,
ultimately leading to significant amendments that diluted the bill's original intent.
• The controversy underscored the complexities of governance and racial dynamics in colonial India, reflecting broader tensions between imperial policies and local aspirations for justice and equality.

questions.question:
The Curzon-Kitchener controversy, significant in India’s freedom struggle and
colonial history, primarily relates to:

options.text: Indian National Army's formation during World War II.
Salt March led by Mahatma Gandhi.
Military reforms and control of the army.

questions.explanation:
Option (d) is correct
• The Curzon-Kitchener controversy refers to the clash between Lord Curzon, the Viceroy of India, and
Lord Kitchener, the Commander-in-Chief of the British Indian Army, during the early 20th century.
• The dispute arose primarily over the issue of military command and control.
• Lord Curzon, known for his administrative reforms and often described as a micro-manager, sought
greater authority over military matters in India.
• On the other hand, Lord Kitchener, a distinguished military leader, asserted the importance of maintaining
military autonomy and operational freedom.
• This conflict led to significant tensions between civil and military authorities in British India, reflecting
broader debates over governance and military policy within the British Empire.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding Lord Ripon:
1. The Vernacular Press Act (1878) was passed during his viceroyship.
2. He continued the policy of financial decentralization during his period.
3. He appointed Education Commission under chairmanship of Sir William Hunter (1882).
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• Vernacular Press Act (1878):
 Lord Lytton was alarmed by the impact of the vernacular press on the people. To curb the freedom
of the vernacular press, the Vernacular Press Act, modelled on the Irish Press Laws, was passed on
March 14, 1878.
 The Act was enacted to suppress the seditious writing in vernacular press. Hence, it was also known
as "The Gagging Act."
 Under Vernacular Press Act, the district magistrate was empowered to force the printer and publisher of a newspaper to agree not to publish certain kinds of material, demand security, and confiscate any printed matter it deemed objectionable.
 When a newspaper published a seditious report, it was warned. If the warning was ignored, the press
could be seized and printing machinery confiscated.
 The Government was empowered to issue search warrants and enter newspaper premises without
court orders.
 The magistrate's decision was final, and there was no provision for an appeal.
 This Act seriously restricted the freedom of Indian-language newspapers and excluded Englishlanguage publications.
 To escape the Vernacular Press Act, the Amrita Bazar Patrika, a bilingual newspaper published in
Bengali and English, became solely an English weekly overnight.
• Repealing the Vernacular Press Act
 The Vernacular Press Act evoked widespread opposition in India and, to some extent, in England, too.
Indian public opinion was now fully aroused, and it protested loudly against its passage.
 This protest had an immediate effect, and Lord Ripon repealed the Act in 1881.
Statements 2 and 3 are correct
• The Government of Ripon desired the provincial governments to apply in case of local bodies the same
principle of financial decentralisation which Lord Mayo’s Government had begun towards them.
• For his contributions, Lord Ripon is called father of local self-government in India.
• During his tenure, Lord Ripon appointed the Education Commission in 1882 under the chairmanship of
Sir William Hunter.
• The commission, known as the Hunter Commission, was tasked with examining the state of education
in India and making recommendations for its improvement.
• This initiative reflected Lord Ripon's commitment to social reforms and modernisation efforts in education, aiming to expand access and quality of schooling across British India.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the tenure of Lord Mayo:
1. It was during his time that the Statistical Survey of India was established.
2. He established the Department of Agriculture and Commerce.
3. State railways were introduced during this time.
Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
All three statements are correct
• Lord Mayo, who served as Viceroy of India from 1869 to 1872, oversaw several significant developments in British India.
• Under his administration, the Statistical Survey of India was established, marking a crucial step in gathering comprehensive data about the country's demographics, economy, and geography.
• Additionally, Lord Mayo initiated the establishment of the Department of Agriculture and Commerce,
recognising the importance of promoting agricultural productivity and commercial activities in India.
• Another milestone during his tenure was the introduction of state-owned railways, aimed at improving
transportation infrastructure and facilitating economic development across the subcontinent.
• These initiatives underscored Lord Mayo's efforts to modernise and integrate various aspects of administration and infrastructure in British India during the late 19th century.

questions.question: The Policy of proud reserve is related to which one of the following?
questions.explanation:
Option (a) is correct

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
1. Increased the minimum age (from 7 to 9 years) & the maximum (from 12 to 14 years) for children.
2. Reduced maximum working hours for children to 7 hours a day.
3. Fixed maximum working hours for women at 11 hours per day with a one-and-a-half-hour interval.
Which of the above are the provisions related to the Factory Act of 1881?
questions.explanation:
