3. Western Disturbances are now more prevalent in early winter than in summer.
Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• These Western Disturbances (Western depressions) are residual frontal cyclones that move at the
height of 2000 meters from the mean sea level. On the way, they pick up moisture from the Caspian Sea
and the Black Sea.
• Meteorologists believe that the southern branch of the jet stream exercises a significant influence on
the winter weather conditions in India.
• The southern branch of the jet stream is responsible for steering the Western Disturbances from the
Mediterranean Sea.
Statement 2 is correct
• The arrival of these temperate storms (remnants of temperate cyclones) causes precipitation, leading
to an abrupt decrease in air temperature over North-West India.
• Winter rain and heat storms in north-western plains, occasional heavy snowfall in hilly regions, and
cold waves in the northern plains are caused by these disturbances.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• On average, 4 to 6 cyclonic waves reach north-western India between October and April each year.
• Some of these depressions continue eastwards, redeveloping in the zone of jet stream confluence around
30° N, 105° E (near the east coast of China).
• Recent studies indicate that the number of Western Disturbances reaching India has increased in the
early summer period, which now outnumbers those arriving in the late winter.

questions.question:
Consider the following factors:
1. Favorable for monsoon rainfall
2. Promotes cyclogenesis in the Arabian Sea region
3. Flooding is prevalent
How many of the above-mentioned are the effects of El-Nino in the Indian climate?
questions.explanation:
Option 2 is correct
• El Niño has a negative impact on monsoon rainfall in India, often leading to drought conditions
rather than being good for monsoons.
• While El Niño suppresses cyclogenesis in the Bay of Bengal, it is favorable for cyclogenesis in the
Arabian Sea.
• El Niño is commonly associated with droughts due to reduced monsoonal and cyclonic rainfall.
Options 1 and 3 are incorrect
• La Niña has a positive impact on monsoon rainfall in India, making it good for monsoon rainfall.
• It enhances cyclogenesis in the Bay of Bengal, leading to more frequent and intense cyclones in that
region.
• La Niña is associated with an increased likelihood of floods due to the excessive rainfall during the
monsoon season.

questions.question:
How many of the following are the features of Monsoon Winds in India?
1. Sudden onset
2. Gradual progress
3. Sudden retreat
4. Seasonal reversal of winds
Select the correct answer from the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Options 1, 2 and 4 are correct, Option 3 is incorrect
• The most dominating factor of the Indian climate is the 'monsoon winds'. Important features of Indian
Monsoons are:
❖ Sudden onset: The monsoon season begins with a sudden burst of rainfall.
❖ Gradual progress: The monsoon advances gradually across the country.
❖ Gradual retreat: The monsoon season recedes gradually.
❖ Seasonal reversal of winds: There is a complete reversal of wind direction between summer and
winter, leading to a change in seasons. The harsh summer season suddenly gives way to monsoon
or rainy season.
• The south-west monsoons from the Arabian Sea and the Bay of Bengal bring rainfall to the country.
• The north-eastern winter monsoon does not cause much rainfall except along the Coromandel coast
(TN coast) after getting moisture from the Bay of Bengal.

questions.question:
With reference to the local winds and thunderstorms prevailing in India, consider the following pairs:
Local winds/thunderstorms Characteristic feature
1. Loo - Hot, dry and fatal in northwestern region
2. Kaal Baisakhi - Rains, winds in eastern region
3. Mango shower -  Rains during end of summer in southern region
How many of the pairs given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
All pairs are correctly matched
• A striking feature of the hot weather season is the ‘loo’. These are strong, gusty, hot, dry winds blowing
during the day over the north and northwestern India. Sometimes they even continue until late in the
evening. Direct exposure to these winds may even prove to be fatal.
• Dust storms are very common during the month of May in northern India. These storms bring temporary relief as they lower the temperature and may bring light rain and cool breeze. This is also the
season for localised thunderstorms, associated with violent winds, torrential downpours, often accompanied by hail. In West Bengal, these storms are known as the ‘Kaal Baisakhi’.
• Towards the close of the summer season, pre-monsoon showers are common especially, in Kerala and
Karnataka. They help in the early ripening of mangoes and are often referred to as ‘mango-showers’.

questions.question:
With reference to rainfall patterns in India, consider the following statements:
1. In advancing monsoon, rainfall in the Ganga valley decreases from the east to the west.
2. Mawsynram in the southern ranges of the Jaintia Hills receives the highest average rainfall in the
world.
Which of the statements given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• The inflow of the south-west monsoon into India brings about a total change in the weather.
• Early in the season, the windward side of the Western Ghats receives very heavy rainfall, more than
250 cm.
• The Deccan Plateau and parts of Madhya Pradesh also receive some amount of rain in spite of lying in
the rain shadow area.
• Rainfall in the Ganga valley decreases from the east to the west.
• Rajasthan and parts of Gujarat get scanty rainfall.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• The maximum rainfall of this season is received in the north-eastern part of the country.
• Mawsynram in the southern ranges of the Khasi Hills receives the highest average rainfall in the
world.

questions.question:
With reference to climate controls, consider the following statements:
1. There are 5 major controls of the climate of any place.
2. Major climate controls include latitude, altitude, pressure and wind system, distance from the sea
(continentality), ocean currents etc.
3. Relief plays a minor role in determining the climate of a place.
Which of the statements given above are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 2 is correct and Statements 1 and 3 are incorrect
• There are six major controls of the climate of any place.
• They are latitude, altitude, pressure and wind system, distance from the sea (continentality), ocean
currents and relief features.
• Due to the curvature of the earth, the amount of solar energy received varies according to latitude. As a
result, air temperature generally decreases from the equator towards the poles.
• As one goes from the surface of the earth to higher altitudes the atmosphere becomes less dense and
temperature decreases. The hills are therefore cooler during summers.
• The pressure and wind system of any area depend on the latitude and altitude of the place. Thus, it
influences the temperature and rainfall pattern.
• The sea exerts a moderating influence on climate: As the distance from the sea increases, its moderating influence decreases and the people experience extreme weather conditions. This condition is
known as continentality (i.e. very hot during summers and very cold during winters).
• Ocean currents along with onshore winds affect the climate of the coastal areas, for example, any coastal
area with warm or cold currents flowing past it, will be warmed or cooled if the winds are onshore.
• Finally, relief too plays a major role in determining the climate of a place. High mountains act as barriers
for cold or hot winds; they may also cause precipitation if they are high enough and lie in the path of
rain-bearing winds. The leeward side of mountains remains relatively dry

questions.question: What does the term ‘Mahawat’ imply with respect to Indian climate?

options.text: It is the total amount of winter rainfall.
It is another name for the western disturbances.
It is a cold local wind over the northern plains.
It is a reference for the shepherd in the northern plains.

questions.explanation:
Option (a) is correct and all other options are incorrect
• A characteristic feature of the cold weather season over the northern plains is the inflow of cyclonic
disturbances from the west and the northwest.
• These low-pressure systems, originate over the Mediterranean Sea and western Asia and move into
India, along with the westerly flow.
• They cause the much-needed winter rains over the plains and snowfall in the mountains.
• Although the total amount of winter rainfall locally known as ‘Mahawat’ is small, they are of immense
importance for the cultivation of ‘rabi’ crops.

questions.question:
With reference to the winter in India:
1. The temperature decreases from south to the north.
2. Frost is common in the north and the higher slopes of the Himalayas experience snowfall.
3. In northern India, the weather is normally marked by clear sky, low temperatures and low humidity
and feeble, variable winds.
Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
All statements are correct
• The cold weather season begins from mid-November in northern India and stays till February.
• December and January are the coldest months in the northern part of India.
• The temperature decreases from south to the north.
• The average temperature of Chennai, on the eastern coast, is between 24°– 25° Celsius, while in the
northern plains, it ranges between 10°C and 15° Celsius.
• Days are warm and nights are cold.
• Frost is common in the north and the higher slopes of the Himalayas experience snowfall. During
this season, the northeast trade winds prevail over the country.
• They blow from land to sea and hence, for most part of the country, it is a dry season.
• Some amount of rainfall occurs on the Tamil Nadu coast from these winds as, here they blow from sea
to land. In the northern part of the country, a feeble high-pressure region develops, with light winds
moving outwards from this area. Influenced by the relief, these winds blow through the Ganga valley
from the west and the northwest.
• The weather is normally marked by clear sky, low temperatures and low humidity and feeble, variable
winds.

questions.question:
With reference to alluvial soils, consider the following statements:
1. They are the largest soil group in India covering more than half of the total area.
2. The proportion of Potash, Phosphorus and Nitrogen are adequate in alluvial soil.
3. They are well known for Kankar beds or calcareous concentrations.
4. They are found along river courses and occur all along Indo-Ganga-Brahmaputra plains.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statements 1, 2 and 4 are incorrect
• Alluvial soils are the largest soil group covering about 15 lakh sq km or about 45.6 percent of the total
area. They support more than 40 percent of India’s population by providing the most productive agricultural lands.
• Due to their recent origin, they are immature and have weak profiles. Being porous due to loamy
structure, the soil provides good drainage and other conditions favourable for agriculture.
• Replenished constantly by recurring floods, they occur all along the Indo-Gangetic-Brahmaputra
plains except where the top layer is covered by desert sand. Known as deltaic alluvium, they also occur
in deltas of the Mahanadi, Godavari, Krishna and Cauvery.
• The proportion of nitrogen is generally low, whereas potash, phosphoric acid (phosphate) and alkalis
(lime) are adequate. Iron oxide and lime vary widely.
Statement 3 is correct
• Kankar beds or calcareous concentrations in some regions along the river terraces are a characteristic
of alluvial soil.
• Geologically, the alluvium of the Great Plain of India is divided into newer or younger khadar and older
bhangar soils.

questions.question:
Which of the following factors can affect soil salinity?
1. Evaporation
2. Capillary action
3. Excessive groundwater exploitation
4. Deforestation
5. Overgrazing
Select the correct answer from the codes given below:
questions.explanation:
All options are correct
• Salinity refers to the amount of salt in the soil which includes calcium, magnesium, potassium, sodium,
chloride, carbonate, sulfate etc.
• The process of increase in the soil salinity (salinization) can be caused by natural or artificial factors.
• The natural factor for salinization includes mineral weathering, capillary action, hot arid and semiarid
climates, low water tables and widening of shore etc.
• The man-made factor for salinization includes irrigation, excessive groundwater exploitation, deforestation and overgrazing practices etc.
• Soil salinity can negatively affect plant development along with land and water quality degradation,
reduced infiltration, surface cracking etc.
• Mitigation of soil salinity includes better water management, mulching, soil treatment using gypsum or
biochar, avoiding deep tillage, afforestation and encouragement of organic farming etc.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
1. Statement- I: The Brahmaputra River exhibits syntaxial bending as it carves a deep gorge in the Himalayas before entering India.
2. Statement- II: Syntaxial bending refers to the bending or folding of rock layers due to tectonic forces.
Which one of the following is correct in respect of above statements?

options.text: Both statement-I and statement-II are correct and Statement- II is the correct explanation for Statement –I

Both statement-I and statement-II are correct and Statement- II is not the correct explanation for
Statement –I
Statement-I is correct but Statement-II is incorrect
Statement-I is incorrect but Statement-II is correct

questions.explanation:
Both statement-I and statement-II are correct and Statement- II is not the correct explanation for
Statement –I
• The Brahmaputra River, along with the other rivers (Irrawaddy, Mekong), originates in Tibet and flows
through narrow and parallel mountain ranges in its upper reaches.
• However, unlike the others, the Brahmaputra makes a distinct "U" turn in its course. This peculiar
feature is primarily due to the syntaxial bending of the geologically young Himalayas.
• Syntaxial bending refers to the bending or folding of rock layers due to tectonic forces.
• In the case of the Brahmaputra River, as it approaches the Himalayas, it encounters the young and
actively growing mountain ranges.
• The intense tectonic activity in this region causes the rocks to bend, resulting in the unique U-shaped
course of the river as it navigates around the eastern end of the Himalayas and flows into India.

questions.question:
Highly argillaceous and found in regions of high temperature and low rainfall,
this soil is good at retaining moisture. In southern part of the country, gneisses and
schists forms its parent material. Which one of the following is the above-mentioned soil?
questions.explanation:
Option (c) is correct
• The parent materials for most of the black soil are volcanic rocks formed in Deccan plateau. In Tamil
Nadu and parts of Andhra Pradesh, gneisses and schists form the parent material.
• Black soil is found in regions of high temperature and low rainfall and is typical to dry and hot regions
of the peninsula.
• A highly argillaceous with a large clay factor, black soil is good at retaining moisture for a longer
duration.
• These soils are usually poor in nitrogen, organic compounds, phosphorus and sulfur.
• Black soil is black due to its high iron, aluminum, and humus content.
• Black soil is also termed as regur soil and cotton soil as it is good for cotton growth. They are generally
fertile because they contain decaying organic matter, humus, and other nutrients. Fertility is higher for
valley soil than for upland.
• It is unique for its self-ploughing capacity. Hard when it is dry, on accumulating moisture, the soil swells
greatly and gets very sticky.
• Spread over 46 lakh sq km (16.6 per cent of the total area) across Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, parts of
Karnataka, Telangana, Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat and Tamil Nadu.
• The crops grown in black soil include Sugarcane, wheat, jawar, rice, citrus fruits, sunflower, linseed.

questions.question:
This state is well known for soil, which is an end product of weathering under
high temperature and heavy rainfall with alternate wet and dry periods. Deficient
in nutrients, the soil is more gravel in nature supporting plantation crops in the
state. Which of the following states/UT suits the above description?
questions.explanation:
Option (b) correct
• Laterite soils are mostly an end product of weathering under high temperature and heavy rainfall
with alternate wet and dry periods.
• Heavy rainfall promotes leaching of soil whereby minerals or lime and silica are leached away and soil
rich in oxides of iron and aluminium compounds is left behind.
• Laterite soils are red in colour due to little clay and more gravel of red sandstones.
• Rich in bauxite or ferric oxides, they are very poor in lime, magnesia, potash and nitrogen. Sometimes, the phosphate content may be high in the form of iron phosphate and in wetter places, there
may be higher content of humus.
• Since it lacks fertility due to intensive leaching, when manured and irrigated, some laterites are suitable for growing plantation crops like tea, coffee, rubber, cinchona, coconut, arecanut, etc.
• In some areas, these soils support grazing grounds and scrub forests.
• Laterite and lateritic soils also provide valuable building material.
• These soils are mainly found in Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Madhya Pradesh, and the hilly areas of
Odisha and Assam. After adopting appropriate soil conservation techniques particularly in the hilly areas
of Karnataka, Kerala and Tamil Nadu, this soil is very useful for growing tea and coffee.
• Red laterite soils in Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh and Kerala are more suitable for crops like cashew nut.

questions.question: Which of the following options correctly describes alluvial fans?

options.text:
Depression in a stream bed or river channel at the base of a waterfall, formed by the erosive forces
of cascading water.
Narrow ridges of low height on sides of a river, formed due to deposition action of the stream, appearing as natural embankments.
Tract of alluvium at the mouth of a river where it deposits more material than can be carried away.
The eroded material from the mountains by streams due to low gradient deposited at the foothills.

questions.explanation:
Option (d) is correct
• When a stream leaves the mountains and comes down to the plains, its velocity decreases due to a
lower gradient, due to which, it sheds a lot of material, which had been carrying from the mountains, at
the foothills.
• This deposited material acquires a conical shape and appears as a series of continuous fans which are
called alluvial fans.
• Such fans appear throughout the Himalayan foothills in the north Indian plains.
Option (a) is incorrect
• Plunge pools are the depression in a stream bed or river channel at the base of a waterfall, formed by
the erosive forces of cascading water.
Option (b) is incorrect
• Natural levees are the narrow ridges of low height on sides of a river, formed due to deposition action
of the stream, appearing as natural embankments
Option (c) is incorrect
• Deltas are the tract of alluvium at the mouth of a river where it deposits more material than can be carried
away.

questions.question:
With reference to peninsular and extra-peninsular soils, consider the following
statements:
1. Peninsular soils are formed due to deposition by rivers and wind whereas Extra-peninsular soils are
formed due to decomposition of rocks in situ.
2. Most of the peninsular soils are fine silt and clay whereas extra-peninsular soils are generally coarsegrained.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statements 1 and 2 are incorrect
• Geologically, Indian soils can broadly be divided into soils of peninsular India and soils of extra-peninsular India.
• The soils of Peninsular India are formed by the decomposition of rocks in situ, i.e. directly from the
underlying rocks.
• Soils of Peninsular India are transported and re-deposited to a limited extent and are known as sedentary soils.
• The soils of the Extra-Peninsula are formed due to the depositional work of rivers and wind. They are
very deep. They are often referred to as transported or azonal soils.
• Most of the extra-peninsular soils are alluvial soils, which are very fertile because of the presence of
fine silt and clay and constant replenishment by the Himalayan rivers.
• Unlike the alluvial soils of the plains, the soils of the peninsular plateau are generally coarse-grained.
• These soils are generally more mature but less fertile.

questions.question:
With reference to the Indian ocean dipole, consider the following statements:
1. Western pole is in the Arabian Sea and Eastern pole in the Bay of Bengal.
2. IOD develops in the equatorial region of Indian Ocean from April to May peaking in October
3. Positive IOD results in the Arabian Sea being much warmer and Bay of Bengal colder and dry.
How many statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
All statements are correct
• IOD is defined by the difference in sea surface temperature between two areas (or poles, hence a
dipole).
• Western pole in the Arabian Sea and Eastern pole in the Bay of Bengal.
• IOD develops in the equatorial region of Indian Ocean from April to May peaking in October.
• Positive IOD occurs when
❖ Winds over the Indian Ocean blow from east to west (from Bay of Bengal towards Arabian Sea).
❖ This results in the Arabian Sea being much warmer and Bay of Bengal colder and dry.
• Negative IOD occurs when
❖ Winds over the Indian Ocean blow from west to east (from Arabian Sea towards Bay of Bengal).
❖ This results in the Bay of Bengal being much warmer and Arabian ocean colder and dry.

questions.question:
With reference to the southwest monsoon and its impact on South Asia, consider
the following statements:
1. Statement-I: In the Indian subcontinent, the low temperatures and high-pressure during summer generate a thermal low, leading to the onset of the southwest monsoon.
2. Statement-II: Due to the Earth's rotation, the air masses moving towards the low-pressure system
from the Indian Ocean get deflected and flow in a southwesterly direction, bringing moisture-laden
air from the ocean towards the land.
Which one of the following is correct in respect of the above statements?

options.text: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct, and Statement II is the correct explanation for Statement I.

Both Statement I and Statement II are correct, but Statement II is not the correct explanation for
Statement I.
Statement I is correct, but Statement II is not correct.
Statement I is not correct, but Statement II is correct.

questions.explanation:
Statement I is not correct, but Statement II is correct
• During summer in the Indian subcontinent, high temperatures and low pressure create a thermal low
over the region.
• This low-pressure system acts like a "vacuum," drawing in air from surrounding areas with higher
pressure.
• South-west monsoon winds: Due to the Earth's rotation (Coriolis effect), the air masses moving towards the low-pressure system from the Indian Ocean get deflected and flow in a southwesterly direction, bringing moisture-laden air from the ocean towards the land.
• This is the south-west monsoon that brings crucial rainfall to India and other parts of South Asia.

questions.question:
Which of the following factors influence the onset of the monsoon?
1. Subtropical Jet Stream (STJ)
2. Tropical Easterly Jet (African Easterly Jet)
3. Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ)
4. Permanent high-pressure cell (Mascarene High) in the South Intense heating of the Tibetan Plateau
during summer months
Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
questions.explanation:
Monsoons are Periodic or Secondary winds that reverse their direction with the change of season.
• They can be called land and sea breezes on a large scale or convection cells on a large scale.
• They are a double system of seasonal winds — they flow from sea to land during the summer (southwest monsoon winds) and from land to sea during winter (north-east monsoon winds).
All options are correct
• Factors that influence the onset of south-west monsoons:
❖ Intense heating of the Tibetan Plateau during summer months
❖ Permanent high-pressure cell (Mascarene High) in the South Indian Ocean (east to northeast of
Madagascar in summer).
❖ Subtropical Jet Stream (STJ)
❖ Tropical Easterly Jet (African Easterly Jet)
❖ Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ)

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the monsoon season in India:
1. The duration of the monsoon season increases as one moves from southern to northern India.
2. Rainfall in the northern plains of India decreases from east to west.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• The duration of the monsoon season decreases gradually from southern to northern India.
• This is because the monsoon season begins in southern India (Kerala) around June and extends northward, covering the entire country by mid-July.
• The retreat of the monsoon begins first in the north and gradually progresses towards the south.
Rainfall in the northern plains decreases from east to west.
• The northern plains receive most rainfall from south-west monsoon winds carrying moisture from the
Indian Ocean.
Statement 2 is correct
• As the monsoon progresses inland in the northern plains, it loses moisture, resulting in a decrease in
rainfall from east to west across the northern plains.
• States like West Bengal and Bihar in the eastern part of the northern plains receive higher rainfall compared to states like Haryana and Punjab in the western part

questions.question:
With respect to the Indian Monsoon, consider the following statements:
1. During El Nino events, the central and eastern equatorial Pacific Ocean becomes warmer than usual,
which can disrupt atmospheric circulation patterns globally, including the Indian monsoon.
2. El Nino-associated alterations in wind patterns can enhance the Indian monsoon, resulting in substantial rainfall over the subcontinent.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Impact of El Niño on Indian Monsoon:
❖ During El Niño events, the central and eastern equatorial Pacific Ocean becomes warmer than
usual.
❖ This disrupts the atmospheric circulation patterns, impacting global weather patterns, including
the Indian monsoon.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• El Niño-related changes in wind patterns can weaken the Indian monsoon, leading to reduced rainfall
over the subcontinent

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding factors affecting the Monsoon
break:
1. A negative Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) is characterized by cooler sea surface temperatures in the western Indian Ocean, which can weaken the monsoon in India.
2. The Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) is a phenomenon that moves eastward and can influence the
monsoon break in India.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Monsoon break occurs when the monsoon trough shifts northward to the Himalayan foothills.
❖ The monsoon trough is the elongated low-pressure area over the Indian subcontinent formed by
the northward shifting of ITCZ.
❖ It serves as a focal point for the convergence of moisture-laden winds, leading to widespread rainfall.
❖ The position and intensity of the monsoon trough influence the distribution of rainfall across different parts of India. When the monsoon trough shifts northward, it brings rainfall to the northern
plains and parts of central India.
❖ This enhances rainfall in the Himalayan states, while for the rest of India, rainfall is suppressed or
temporarily interrupted.
Statement 1 is correct
• Factors that Can Cause Monsoon Break:
❖ Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD): A negative IOD is characterized by cooler sea surface temperatures
in the western Indian Ocean. This can lead to a weaker monsoon in India.
❖ Cyclones: A cyclonic circulation in the Arabian Sea sucks up moisture that’s supposed to reach
India. If it turns westwards towards Yemen, it will further take away moisture and stall the monsoon.
Statement 2 is correct
• Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO): It is an eastward-moving trough (series of thunderstorms) in the
tropics that recurs every 30 to 60 days. It is characterized by alternating periods of enhanced and suppressed rainfall. A suppressed MJO can lead to a monsoon break in India.
• El Nino Event: El Nino is the warm phase of ENSO, which is characterized by cooler ocean temperatures in the western Pacific. It leads to a weaker monsoon with prolonged breaks

questions.question:
With respect to Indian monsoon, consider the following statements:
1. Monsoon refers to the seasonal reversal of winds, and in India, the monsoon season typically lasts
from June to September.
2. The Western Ghats, north-east India, and Meghalaya receive abundant rainfall, with annual precipitation ranging from 100 to 200 cm.
3. A monsoon break occurs when the monsoon trough shifts northward to the Himalayan foothills, leading to a temporary halt in rainfall over the Indian subcontinent.
Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics of the Indian Monsoon:
❖ Monsoon rainfall is a vital component of India's climate, as it plays a crucial role in determining agricultural productivity, water resources, and overall socio-economic development.
Statement 1 is correct
• Monsoon refers to the seasonal reversal of winds.
• In India, the monsoon season typically lasts from June to September. During this time, winds blow from
the south-west, bringing moist air from the Indian Ocean.
• This is known as the south-west monsoon.
• After September, winds reverse their direction, coming from the north-east, marking the onset of the
north-east monsoon.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• Monsoon rainfall in India exhibits significant variability both spatially and temporally.
• Different regions experience varying amounts of rainfall, with some areas receiving abundant precipitation while others face drought-like conditions.
• This variability can occur within the same monsoon season or between different years.
• For example, the Indian states of Rajasthan and Gujarat are known for their arid climate and often experience scanty rainfall during the monsoon season.
• India Meteorological Department (IMD) brands the monsoon as ‘normal’ or ‘deficient’ based on how
it fares against its benchmark Long Period Average (LPA).
❖ LPA is the average rainfall received by the country as a whole during the south-west monsoon,
for a 50-year period.
❖ The current LPA is 89 cm, based on the average rainfall between 1951 and 2000. This serves as a
benchmark against which the rainfall in any monsoon season is measured.
❖ The country is said to have received deficient rainfall if the actual rainfall falls below 90% of LPA.
❖ Similarly, the country is said to have received excess rainfall if the rainfall is greater than 110% of
LPA.
❖ It is deemed ‘normal’ when the actual rainfall received falls between 96 and 104 % of LPA.
• High Rainfall: Western Ghats, north-east India, Meghalaya (250-400 cm) receive abundant rain.
• Moderate Rainfall: Central India, Gangetic plains (100-200 cm) see moderate amounts of rainfall.
• Low Rainfall: Western Rajasthan, Ladakh (<100mm) witness scarce rainfall.
• Mountains like the Himalayas influence rainfall patterns, causing orographic uplift and increased precipitation on windward sides.
Statement 3 is correct
• The monsoon trough is the elongated low-pressure area over the Indian subcontinent formed by the
northward shifting of ITCZ.
• It serves as a focal point for the convergence of moisture-laden winds, leading to widespread rainfall.
• The position and intensity of the monsoon trough influence the distribution of rainfall across different
parts of India. When the monsoon trough shifts northward, it brings rainfall to the northern plains
and parts of central India.
• Monsoon break occurs when the monsoon trough shifts northward to the Himalayan foothills. This
enhances rainfall in the Himalayan states, while for the rest of India, rainfall is suppressed or temporarily interrupted.
• Monsoon break happens especially in the core monsoon zone area (the region stretching from Gujarat
in the west to West Bengal and Odisha in the east).
• These breaks can last for several days to a few weeks and are characterized by the weakening of the
monsoon circulation.
• Shifting of monsoon trough southward resumes vigorous monsoon over major part of India.
• Climatologically, a monsoonal break is declared when the normalized rainfall anomaly index (i.e., deviation from the long-term rainfall average over the core monsoon zone) exceeds the -1 threshold, and
the situation persists for at least three consecutive days.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about the Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) is not
correct?

options.text:
The Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) is defined by the difference in sea surface temperature between a
western pole in the Arabian Sea and an eastern pole in the eastern Indian Ocean south of Indonesia.

The IOD develops in the equatorial region of the Indian Ocean from April to May, peaking in October,
with a positive IOD leading to cooler sea surface temperatures in the Arabian Sea.

In the negative dipole phase, Indonesia becomes much warmer and rainier, while the western Indian
Ocean around the Arabian Sea becomes cooler and drier.

The atmospheric component of the IOD, named Equatorial Indian Ocean Oscillation (EQUINOO), exhibits enhanced cloud formation and rainfall in the western part of the equatorial ocean near the
African coast during the positive phase.

questions.explanation:
Option (a) is correct
• Indian Ocean Dipole is a recently discovered phenomenon that has a significant influence on Indian
monsoons.
• It is a Sea Surface Temperature (SST) Anomaly (different from normal) that occurs occasionally in the
Northern or Equatorial Indian Ocean Region (IOR).
• The Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) is defined by the difference in sea surface temperature between two areas
(or poles, hence a dipole) — a western pole in the Arabian Sea (western Indian Ocean) and an eastern
pole in the eastern Indian Ocean south of Indonesia.
Option (b) is incorrect
• IOD develops in the equatorial region of the Indian Ocean from April to May, peaking in October.
• With positive IOD, winds over the Indian Ocean blow from east to west (from the Bay of Bengal towards
the Arabian Sea). This results in the Arabian Sea being much warmer and the eastern Indian Ocean
around Indonesia becoming colder and dry.
Option (c) is correct
• In the negative dipole year, the reverse happens, making Indonesia much warmer and rainier.
• Positive IOD is good for Indian Monsoons as more evaporation occurs in warm water.
Option (d) is correct
• Similar to ENSO, the atmospheric component of the IOD is named Equatorial Indian Ocean Oscillation
(EQUINOO) (Oscillation of pressure cells between the Bay of Bengal and the Arabian Sea).
• During the positive phase of the EQUINOO, there is enhanced cloud formation and rainfall in the western part of the equatorial ocean near the African coast.
• At the same time, such activity is suppressed near Sumatra.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the Somali Jet and its influence on
the Indian monsoon:
1. The Somali Jet strengthens the southwest monsoon and flows from Mauritius and Madagascar to the
coast of Kenya.
2. The Findlater Current in the Arabian Sea reverses its direction with the monsoon winds and creates a
zone of coastal upwelling near the Horn of Africa.
3. The coastal upwelling caused by the Findlater Current significantly impacts the Indian monsoon due
to its large scale.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• The progress of the south-west monsoon towards India is greatly aided by the onset of the Somali jet
that transits Kenya, Somalia, and the Sahel.
• It was observed to flow from Mauritius and the northern part of the island of Madagascar before
reaching the coast of Kenya at about 3° S.
• It strengthens permanent high near Madagascar and also helps to drive south-west monsoons towards India at a greater pace and intensity (it intensifies the monsoon cell). The current in the Arabian
Sea associated with the Somali Jet is called the Findlater Current.
• The monsoon winds influence its direction.
• It reverses its direction with the monsoon winds.
Statement 2 is correct
• Findlater Current in the south-west monsoon season creates a zone of coastal upwelling near the
horn of Africa (good for fishing).
Statement 3 is incorrect
• Findlater Current doesn’t have a significant impact on Indian Monsoons because the zone of
upwelling is very small unlike in the case of Indian Ocean Dipole.

questions.question:
With reference to the seasonal weather patterns in India, consider the following
statements:
1. Statement-I: The burst of monsoons depends upon the upper air circulation, which is dominated by
Sub-tropical Jet stream.
2. Statement-II: The sub-tropical Jet stream is a narrow band of fast-moving air flowing from east to
west.
Which one of the following is correct in respect of the above statements?

options.text: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct, and Statement II is the correct explanation for Statement I.

Both Statement I and Statement II are correct, but Statement II is not the correct explanation for
Statement I
Statement I is correct, but Statement II is not correct.
Statement I is not correct, but Statement II is correct.

questions.explanation:
Statement I is correct, but Statement II is not correct
• Sub-tropical jet stream plays a significant role in both hindering the monsoon winds and in the quick
onset of monsoons.
• The sub-tropical Jet stream is a narrow band of fast-moving air flowing from west to east (Westerlies).
• STJ in the northern hemisphere flows between 25° to 35° N in the upper troposphere at the height of
about 12-14 km (the height of each portion of the jet stream varies when there is meandering.
• Their path is sometimes influenced by the Greater Himalayas).
• The wind speeds in a westerly jet stream are commonly 150 to 300 kmph, with extreme values reaching
400 kmph.
• The burst of monsoons depends upon the upper air circulation, which is dominated by STJ.
Seasonal Migration of Sub-Tropical Jet Stream (STJ):
❖ In winter, STJ flows along the southern slopes of the Himalayas.
❖ In summer, it shifts northwards rather dramatically and flows along the northern edge of the Himalayas in early June and along the northern Tibetan Plateau in late summer (July-August).
❖ The periodic movement of the Jet stream is often the indicator of the onset (STJ shits to the north
of the Himalayas in a matter of days) and subsequent withdrawal (STJ returns to its position — south
of the Himalayas) of the monsoon.
❖ Northward movement of the subtropical jet is the first indication of the onset of the monsoon
over India.

questions.question:
Consider the following pairs:
Glacier State/UT
1. Siachen - Jammu & Kashmir
2. Bara Shigri - Himachal Pradesh
3. Zemu - Assam
How many of the pairs given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is incorrect
• The Siachen Glacier is located in Ladakh between the Saltoro Ridge, a subrange of the Karakoram,
and the main Karakoram Range.
• It is a Piedmont glacier near the Karakoram Pass.
• It is the source of the Nubra River (Tributary of Shyok River) that waters the Nubra Valley near Leh in
the Trans Himalayas.
• It is the largest glacier outside the polar and sub-polar regions and the highest battleground in the
world.
Pair 2 is correct
• Bara Shigri Glacier, located in the Lahaul region, is the largest glacier in Himachal Pradesh.
• It feeds the Chandra River, which, after merging with the Bhaga River at Tandi, forms the Chandrabhaga
or Chenab River.
• Other glaciers of Himachal Pradesh:
❖ Beas Kund: It is located on the Pir Panjal Range near the Rohtang Pass in the Kullu district. This
glacial lake is the source of the Beas River, a tributary of the Sutlej River.
❖ Chhota Shigri Glacier: It lies near the Rohtang Pass in the Lahaul and Spiti Valley, Pir Panjal Range
in HP. It also feeds the Chandra River.
❖ Suraj Tal or Tso Kamtsi Lake: It is a glacial lake near the Baralacha Pass in HP's Lahaul and Spiti
district. The Bhaga River rises from this lake.
❖ Bhadal Glacier: It is located in the Pir Pangal Range in Kangra district. Bhadal Nallah originates
from the Bhadal glacier. The confluence of Bhadal Nallah, Rai Nallah, and Tantgari Nallah forms the
Ravi River.
Pair 3 is incorrect
• The Zemu Glacier is the largest glacier in the Eastern Himalayas. It is located in Sikkim.
• It is at the base of the Kanchendzonga, the world's third-highest mountain, and drains its eastern side.
• It feeds numerous rivers, including the Teesta River, a major tributary of the Brahmaputra.
• Other glaciers of Sikkim:
❖ Teesta Khangse Glacier: It forms a glacial lake at its snout called Khangchung Chho. Teesta River
originates as Chhombo Chhu from this glacial lake.
❖ South Lhonak Lake: It is one of the fastest expanding lakes in the Sikkim Himalaya region. In 2023,
disastrous flash floods occurred in Sikkim due to the GLOF of South Lhonak Lake.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding Bamboo in India:
1. Statement 1: Bamboo culms grow from a dense root rhizome system, with the sympodial rhizomes
forming compact clumps.
2. Statement II: Bamboo is classified as a tree under the Indian Forest Act, amended in 2017, and requires
felling and transit permissions when grown outside forests.
Which one of the following is correct in respect of the above statements?

options.text:
Both Statement I and Statement II are correct and Statement II is the correct explanation for Statement
I.

Both Statement I and Statement II are correct and Statement II is not the correct explanation for
Statement I.
Statement I is correct but Statement II is not correct.
Statement I is not correct but Statement II is correct.

questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Bamboo culms grow from the dense root rhizome system.
• The monopodial rhizome grows horizontally, and the buds develop either upward, generating a culm,
or horizontally, with a new tract of the rhizome.
• The sympodial rhizomes are short and thick, and the culms, which are above the ground, are close
together in a compact clump, which expands evenly around its circumference.
• The clump-forming species are naturally found in tropical regions, and they are not invasive. Some
bamboos are non-clump forming and can be invasive. They are generally found in temperate regions.                                                                                                                                       Statement 2 is incorrect
• According to the National Bamboo Mission, India has the highest area (15 million ha) under bamboo
and is the second richest country after China in bamboo diversity, with 136 species. However, China
exports 68% of the world’s bamboo and rattan products.
• The Indian Forest Act 1927 was amended in 2017 to remove bamboo from the category of trees.
As a result, anyone can undertake cultivation and business in bamboo and its products. Hence, bamboo grown outside forests no longer needs felling and transit permissions.

questions.question:
Consider the following pairs:
Terms Definition
1. Recorded Forest Area
(RFA)
Forests classified based on legal status, may or may not have actual forest
cover.
2. Forest Cover - Patches of land with a tree canopy density of more than 10% and area of
more than 1 ha.
3. Tree Cover - Patches of trees outside RFA with a size of less than 1 ha.
4. Trees Outside Forest Includes trees outside RFA, irrespective of patch size or canopy density.
How many of the pairs given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is correct
• Recorded Forest Area (extent of forest in terms of legal status) primarily consists of Reserved Forests
(RF) and Protected Forests (PF), which have been constituted under the provisions of the Indian Forest
Act 1927 or its counterpart State Acts.
• The term RFA is used for all lands (irrespective of tree cover or canopy density) which have been
notified as forest under any Government Act or Rules or recorded as 'forest' in the Government
records (RFs, PFs, lands classified as forest in revenue records). That is, a RFA may or may not have
forest cover.
Pair 2 is correct
• Forest Cover (FC) includes all patches of land with a tree canopy density of more than 10% and more
than 1 ha in area, irrespective of land use (agroforestry, compensatory forestry), ownership (public or
private), and species of trees (it can even be a plantation).
Pair 3 is correct
• Tree cover includes all patches of trees occurring outside RFA which are of size less than 1 ha, irrespective of canopy density.
• Forest cover and tree cover together are called Forest and Tree Cover. It is the parameter for monitoring progress against the National Forest Policy goal of 33% of the country’s geographical area under
forests.
• The total tree cover of the country has been estimated at 95,748 sq km (a slight increase since 2019).
• States/UTs having maximum tree cover are Maharashtra (12,108 sq km), Rajasthan (8,733 sq km), and
Madhya Pradesh.
• Considering the percentage of the geographical area of States/UTs, the UT of Chandigarh shows the
highest percentage of tree cover (13.16%) followed by Delhi (9.91%) and Kerala (7.26%).
Pair 4 is correct
• Trees Outside Forest refers to all trees outside RFA irrespective of patch size or canopy density, which
could also be larger than 1 ha. Thus, tree cover is a subset of TOF.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about the Indian climate:
1. Statement-I: During winters, the northern half of India is warmer by 3°C to 8°C than other areas located on the same latitudes.
2. Statement-II: Himalayan ranges block the cold air masses moving southwards from Central Asia.
Which one of the following is correct in respect of the above statements?

options.text: Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct, and Statement-II is the correct explanation for Statement-I.

Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct, but Statement-II is not the correct explanation for
Statement-I.
Statement-I is correct, but Statement-II is incorrect.
Statement-I is incorrect, but Statement-II is correct.

questions.explanation:
Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct, and Statement-II is the correct explanation for Statement-I.
• India’s climate closely resembles the climate of a tropical country, although its northern part (north
of the Tropic of Cancer) is situated in the temperate belt.
• The Indian subcontinent is separated from the rest of Asia by the lofty Himalayan ranges, which block
the cold air masses moving southwards from Central Asia. As a result, during winters, the northern half
of India is warmer by 3°C to 8°C than other areas located on the same latitudes

questions.question:
With reference to the features of Indian climate, consider the following statements:
1. The highest diurnal temperature ranges occur in the Himalayan regions, while the Thar Desert records
the highest annual temperature ranges.
2. Both diurnal and mean annual temperature ranges are the lowest in coastal regions.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• Diurnal and annual temperature ranges are substantial in India.
• The highest diurnal temperature ranges occur in the Thar desert, and the highest annual temperature ranges are recorded in the Himalayan regions.
Statement 2 is correct
• Both diurnal and mean annual temperature ranges are the lowest in coastal regions.
• In December, the temperature may dip to –40°C at some places in J&K while in many coastal regions the
average temperature is 20-25°C.
• Winters are moderately cold in most of the regions, while the summers are extremely hot.
• Himalayan regions experience brutal winters while the summers are moderate.

questions.question:
Which of the following are the factors influencing Indian climate?
1. Latitudinal location
2. Distance from the Sea
3. The Himalayas
4. Tropical Cyclones
Select the correct answer from the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Option 1 is correct
• Areas south of the Tropic of Cancer are in the tropics and hence receive high solar insolation.
• The summer temperatures are extreme, and winter temperatures are moderate in most of the regions.
• The northern parts, on the other hand, lie in the warm temperate zone. They receive comparatively less
solar insolation.
• But summer is equally hot here because of the hot local wind called the loo. Winter here is very cold
due to cold waves brought by the western disturbances.
Option 2 is correct
• Coastal regions have a moderate or equable or maritime climate, whereas interior locations are deprived of the moderating influence of the sea and experience extreme or continental climate.
• The monsoon winds first reach the coastal regions and hence bring a good amount of rainfall.
Option 3 is correct
• The Himalayas act as a climatic divide between India and Central Asia.
• During winter, the Himalayas protect India from cold and dry air masses of Central Asia.
• During monsoon months, these mountain ranges act as an effective physical barrier for rain-bearing
south-west monsoon winds (Orographic Rainfall).
• The Himalayas divide the Bay of Bengal branch of monsoon winds into two branches — one branch
flowing along the plain regions towards north-west India and the other towards Southeast Asia.
• If the Himalayas were not present, the monsoon winds would move into China, and most of north
India would have been a desert.
Option 4 is correct
• Tropical cyclones originate in the Bay of Bengal and the Arabian Sea and influence large parts of peninsular India.
• The majority of the cyclones originate in the Bay of Bengal and influence the weather conditions
during the south-west monsoon season (low-intensity cyclones).
• Some cyclones are born during the retreating monsoon season, i.e., in October and November (highintensity cyclones) and influence the weather conditions along the eastern coast of India.

With reference to the effects of upper-air circulation on Indian climate, consider
the following statements:
1. The westerly jet stream blows during summer, while the easterly jet stream blows during winter.
2. The easterly jet stream is responsible for bringing western disturbances into the Indian subcontinent.
3. The westerly jet stream helps in the sudden onset of the southwest monsoons.
Which of the statements given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• Westerly jet stream: Blows during winter at a very high speed over the sub-tropical zone, not during
summer.
• Easterly Jet Stream: The reversal in upper air circulation takes place in summer due to the apparent
shift of the sun's vertical rays in the northern hemisphere.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• The southern branch of the westerly jet stream significantly influences winter weather conditions
in India.
• It is responsible for bringing western disturbances from the Mediterranean region into the Indian
subcontinent, not the easterly jet stream.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• During summer, the westerly jet stream is replaced by the easterly jet stream, which originates from
the heating of the Tibetan Plateau.
• This easterly jet stream contributes to the onset of the southwest monsoons, not the westerly jet stream.

Statement I.
Statement I is correct, but Statement II is not correct.
Statement I is not correct, but Statement II is correct.

• In Western India, particularly over Rajasthan and Gujarat, the southwest monsoon winds blow from the
Arabian Sea towards the northeast.
• These winds generally move in a southwest to northeast direction.
• However, in Rajasthan, the Aravalli Range runs almost parallel to the direction of the monsoon winds,
which reduces the amount of rainfall in the western parts of Rajasthan, such as the Thar Desert.
• The winds do not face a significant barrier to cause orographic rainfall, leading to arid and semi-arid
conditions in the region.
• In contrast, coastal areas like Gujarat receive more rainfall as the winds blow inland from the Arabian
Sea, bringing moisture with them.

questions.question:
Consider the following pairs of soil horizons and their characteristics:
Soil Layer Characteristics
1. Organic Horizon - Zone with surface litter
2. Topsoil Horizon -Zone having humus and inorganic minerals
3. Subsoil Horizon - Zone of leaching
4. Eluviated Horizon- Zone of accumulation
How many of the pairs given above are correctly matched?
questions.explanation:
Pairs 1 and 2 are correctly matched
• Organic horizon is a layer dominated by organic material. They consist of undecomposed or partially
decomposed litter (such as leaves, needles, twigs, moss and lichens) and also include fully decomposed
organic matter (humus).
• A Horizon or surface soil or topsoil Horizon have organic matter mixed with mineral matter. It is often
darker in colour due to its high organic content and is rich in life. This mineral soil layer is depleted of
iron, clay, aluminium, organic compounds and other soluble constituents.
Pairs 3 and 4 are incorrectly matched
• E Horizon is the layer that has been significantly leached of clay, iron and aluminium oxides which
leaves a concentration of resistant minerals, such as quartz, in the sand and silt sizes. These are present
generally in older, well-developed soils and generally occur between the A and B horizons.
• B Horizon or subsoil is a subsurface layer reflecting a chemical or physical alteration of parent material.
It accumulates all the leached minerals from the A and E horizons and is known as zone of illuviation
(accumulation).

questions.question:
With reference to the geological divisions of alluvial soil, consider the following
statements:
1. Bhabar is a porous belt running along the Shiwalik foothills where the streams disappear.
2. Terai is an ill-drained, damp (marshy) and thickly forested narrow tract where the underground
streams of the Bhangar belt re-emerge.
3. Bhangar is the newer alluvium whereas Khadar is the older alluvium found along flood plain.
Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statements 1 and 2 are correct
• The Bhabar belt is about 8-16 km wide running along the Shiwalik foothills as a porous, northern
most stretch of Indo-Gangetic plain.
• Rivers descending from the Himalayas deposit their load along the foothills in the form of alluvial fans
(often pebbly soils) which merge together to build up the Bhabar belt.
• The porosity of Bhabar, which is the most unique feature, is due to deposition of huge number of
pebbles and rock debris across the alluvial fans and because of this feature, the streams disappear once
they reach the Bhabar region.
• Hence, the area is marked by dry river courses except in the rainy season and is not suitable for
agriculture with only big trees having large roots thriving in the belt.
• Terai is an ill-drained, damp (marshy) and thickly forested narrow tract (15-30 km wide) to the south
of Bhabar, running parallel to it.
• The underground streams of the Bhabar belt re-emerge in this belt making it a swampy lowland with
silty soils.
• They are rich in nitrogen and organic matter but deficient in phosphate.
• These soils are generally covered by tall grasses and forests but are suitable for a number of crops such
as wheat, rice, sugarcane, jute etc.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• The Bhangar is the older alluvium along the riverbeds forming terraces higher than the flood plain
(about 30 meters above the flood level), which is of a more clayey composition and is generally dark
colored.
• A few meters below the terrace of the bhangar are beds of lime nodules known as “Kankar”.
• The Khadar is composed of newer alluvium and forms the flood plains along the riverbanks which are
flooded almost every year making them the most fertile soil of Ganges.
• They are sandy clays and loams, drier and more leached, less calcareous and carbonaceous (less
kankary).

2. Tropical monsoons are a dominant climatic feature in India, influencing its tropical nature.

4. Clear skies and intense insolation during winter days raise temperatures to tropical levels, despite low
night temperatures.
How many of the statements given above indicate reasons for India being classified as a tropical country?

Statement 2 is correct

Statement 3 is incorrect
• The tropical nature of India is more due to the influence of the Himalayas and the monsoon system
and not due to the close vicinity to the Equator.
Statement 4 is correct
• Despite low winter night temperatures, clear skies and intense insolation during the day raise temperatures to tropical levels, which is a key characteristic of a tropical climate.

questions.question:
Consider the following organisms:
1. Rhizobium
2. Azotobacter
3. Azospirillium
4. Anabaena
5. Mycorrhizal fungi
How many of the organisms given above are used as bio-fertilisers?
questions.explanation:
One energy-efficient and pollution-free method in agriculture is to exploit the ability of certain microorganisms, such as bacteria, algae, and fungi, to fix atmospheric nitrogen, solubilise phosphorus, decompose organic material, or oxidise sulphur in the soil.
• When applied in the soil, they enhance crop growth and yield, improve soil fertility, and reduce pollution.
They are known as “bio-fertilisers.”
• Thus, bio-fertilisers are living or biologically active products or microbial inoculants of bacteria, algae,
and fungi (separately or in combination) that can enrich the soil with nitrogen, phosphorus, organic matter, etc.
All are correct
• Rhizobium bio-fertiliser
❖ It is a symbiotic bacterium forming root nodules in legume plants.
❖ These nodules act as miniature nitrogen production factories in the fields.
❖ The nodule bacteria fix more nitrogen (N2) than the legume plant and the bacteria need.
❖ The surplus fixed nitrogen is then secreted and fertilised in the soil.
❖ Rhizobium is more efficient than free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria.
• Azotobacter bio-fertiliser
❖ Azotobacter are aerobic, free-living nitrogen fixers.
❖ They grow in the rhizosphere (around the roots), fix atmospheric nitrogen non-symbiotically,
and make it available to cereals.
❖ These bacteria produce growth-promoting hormones which help in enhancing the growth and yield
of the plant.
• Azospirillium bio-fertiliser
❖ These are aerobic living nitrogen fixers that live in associative symbiosis.
❖ In this type of association, bacteria live on the root surface of the host plant and do not form any
nodules with the roots of grasses.
❖ It increases crop yield and its inoculation benefits crop.
❖ They also benefit the host plants by supplying growth hormones and vitamins. These bacteria commonly prepare commercial inoculants (vaccines, culture medium).
• Blue-green algae
❖ Blue-green algae (cyanobacteria) like Nostoc and Anabaena are free-living photosynthetic organisms capable of fixing atmospheric nitrogen.
❖ In the flooded rice fields blue-green algae serves as a nitrogen biofertilizer.
• Mycorrhizal fungi bio-fertiliser
❖ Mycorrhizal fungi are known to occur naturally on the roots of forest trees and crop plants.
❖ They resist disease in plants. The plants also show drought and salinity resistance.
❖ Plants can tolerate adverse soil, pH, high temperature, and heavy metal toxicity.
❖ In soils low in available nutrients, plants infected with Mycorrhiza absorb nutrients more readily.
❖ The fungus dissolves and absorbs phosphorus that plant roots cannot readily absorb.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding Organic Farming:
1. Organic farming avoids using all types of fertilisers, pesticides, growth regulators, and livestock feed
additives.
2. It relies on crop rotation, crop residues, animal manures, legumes, and soil fertility.
Which of the statements given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Organic farming avoids the use of synthetic fertilisers, pesticides, growth regulators, and livestock feed
additives.
• It relies on crop rotation, crop residues, animal manures, legumes, green manure, off-farm organic
wastes, bio fertilisers, mineral-bearing rocks for soil fertility, etc.Organic farmers build healthy soils by nourishing the microbial inhabitants that release, transform, and
transfer nutrients.
• They feed soil biota and build organic matter with cover crops, compost, and biologically based soil
amendments.
• This contributes to good soil structure and water-holding capacity.
• Organic farmers prevent diseases and control pests through good plant nutrition and management.
• They use cover crops and sophisticated crop rotations to change the field ecology, effectively disrupting
the habitat for weeds, insects, and disease organisms.
• They rely on a diverse population of soil organisms, beneficial insects, and birds to keep pests in check.
• When pest populations get out of balance, growers implement a variety of strategies, such as the use of
insect predators, mating disruption, traps, and barriers.
• Weeds are controlled through crop rotation, mechanical tillage, and hand-weeding, as well as through
cover crops, mulches, flame weeding, and other management methods.

questions.question:
With respect to Hydroponics, consider the following statements:
1. This method includes cultivating fish and other aquatic animals within water tanks where the plants
are cultivated.
2. The method reduces water usage and provides superior yield.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• Hydroponics is a method of growing plants without soil, using water enriched with balanced mineral
nutrients essential for plant growth and yield.
• The nutrients and pH level are maintained as per the crop for better growth.
Statement 2 is correct
• With increasing water scarcity due to frequent droughts and declining land availability for farming, government agencies are promoting hydroponics for growing vegetables, fruits, and fodder.
• Hydroponics supports vertical farming (plants are grown on raised beds) and is ideal for growing crops
in congested urban environments.
• The increase in output happens because the cropping cycle is reduced, and the plants don’t have to grow
long roots in search of nutrients.
• It also provides better quality control and better environment and better nutritional value for crops.
• Aquaponics is a method that combines aquaculture (cultivating fish and other aquatic animals in
tanks with organic inputs) with hydroponics, where plants are cultivated in water.
• The difference between aquaponics and hydroponics is that synthetic fertilisers are used in hydroponics for providing nutrients to plants and hence, cultivation of fish is not possible in hydroponics.
• The water from the fish tank is pumped onto the beds where plants grow.
• While the fish excretions provide nutrients for the plants (hence, no chemical fertilisers are needed), the
clean water is recirculated back to the fish tank.
• While the initial cost to set up the facility would be high, the recurring cost is low in aquaponics

questions.question:
With respect to the rice cultivation in India, consider the following statements:
1. Rice is a tropical kharif crop that requires a warm climate and semi-aquatic conditions.
2. Rice is a dominant crop in river valleys, flood plains, deltas, and coastal plains.
3. Rice is primarily grown in areas of high population density.
4. India is the largest producer and consumer of rice in the world followed by China.
How many of the statements given above are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Rice is ideally a kharif crop (a wet and warm climate is ideal for rice cultivation).
• It requires a warm climate and semi-aquatic conditions.
• It is grown only in well-irrigated areas in the rabi season (yield is less in the rabi season compared
to kharif).
• Most of the rice-growing regions lie barren during summer (April-May).
• It can be grown as a summer crop in deltaic regions where water is available throughout the year.
Statements 2 and 3 are correct
• Rice is a dominant crop in river valleys, flood plains, deltas, and coastal plains due to the presence of
loamy and clayey soils.
• Rice is a labour-intensive crop. So, it is primarily grown in areas of high population density to access
labour and ready market.
Statement 4 is incorrect
• India is the 2nd largest producer and consumer of rice in the world after China (148 MT).
• The next largest rice producers are Indonesia (36 MT), Bangladesh (35 MT), Vietnam (27 MT), and Myanmar.

questions.question:
‘This crop is a hardy rainfed kharif crop grown in the dry and warm north-western and western parts of the country. It can withstand frequent dry spells and
drought and is suited for poor light sandy soils as well as black and red soils. It is
also known as Pearl millet.’ Identify the type of crop based on the descriptions.
questions.explanation:
Bajra is the second most important millet.
• It is a rainfed kharif crop of dry and warm north-western and western parts of the country.
• It is a hardy crop that resists frequent dry spells and drought in this region.
• It is grown in areas of 40-50 cm of annual rainfall. The upper limit is 100 cm.
• Just like jowar, it is also used as food and fodder in drier parts of the country.
• Being a rainfed crop, the yield level of this crop fluctuates a lot from year to year.
• Bajra can be grown on poor light sandy soils, and black and red soils.
• It is sown either as a pure or mixed crop with cotton, jowar, and ragi.

questions.question:
Consider the following conditions:
1. Uniform high-temperature
2. low amount of rainfall in the beginning
3. At least 210 frost-free days
4. Moist weather at the time of boll-opening
How many of the conditions given above are unfavourable for cotton cultivation?
questions.explanation:
Cotton is the most important fibre crop.
• Its seed is used in the vanaspati industry and as part of fodder for milch cattle.
• Cotton is a tropical crop grown in the Kharif season in semi-arid areas of the country.
Options 1 and 3 are favourable
• Conditions suitable for the growth of cotton:
❖ Cotton is chiefly a tropical and sub-tropical crop.
❖ It requires uniformly high temperature (21°C to 30°C), light rainfall (50-100 cm) or irrigation, 210
frost-free days, and bright sunshine for its growth.
❖ Most of the irrigated areas under cotton are in Punjab, Haryana, Gujarat, and Rajasthan.
❖ A high amount of rainfall in the beginning (helps in sprouting of seeds) and sunny and dry weather
at flowering and ripening time (moist weather during ripening leads to pest attacks) are very
useful for a good crop.
❖ Deep black soils (regur-lava soil) of the Deccan Plateau, Malwa Plateau, and those of Gujarat are
best suited for cotton cultivation.
❖ It also grows well in alluvial soils of the Sutlej-Ganga Plain and red and laterite soils of the peninsular
region. Cotton quickly exhausts the fertility of the soil.
Options 2 and 4 are unfavourable
• Unfavourable conditions for cotton cultivation:
❖ The growth is retarded below 20 °C.
❖ Frost is enemy number one of the cotton plants. It is grown in areas having at least 210 frost-free
days in a year.
❖ Moist weather and heavy rainfall at the time of boll-opening and picking (rains lead to fibre damage) are detrimental to cotton as the plant becomes vulnerable to pests and diseases.
❖ Almost 65 percent of the area under cotton is rainfed with erratic and poorly distributed rains.
❖ It is also subjected to severe attacks of pests and diseases.

questions.question:
With reference to the Fisheries and Aquaculture in India, consider the following
statements:

shelf.

questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• India is the third largest fish-producing country in the world, accounting for around 8% of global
production.
• This sector employs around 3 crore people.
Statement 2 is correct
• In India, the west coast is more significant for fishing than the east coast due to its extensive continental shelf.
• Like China, aquaculture and inland fisheries contribute most of the fish production (70-80%) compared to commercial marine fishing.
• Technological lag and financial constraints hinder the growth of India's commercial marine fishing industry.
• The case is the same in the Southeast Asian nations. In Southeast Asia, the South China Sea and the Sunda
continental shelf are major fishing grounds.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• India's major fish-producing states are Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Odisha, Tamil Nadu, and West Bengal.

• In FY 2022-23, India recorded its highest-ever export of fisheries and fisheries products (1.73 MMT).
• India’s top export destinations are the USA, China, EU, SE Asia, Japan, and the Middle East.
• India mainly exports frozen shrimp, fish, cuttlefish, squids, dried items, live items, and chilled items.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about the global distribution of the Dairy Industry:
1. The European Union is known as a powerhouse in the global dairy industry.
2. Africa is renowned for its dairy industry, especially for milk powder export.
Which of the statements given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• The European Union (EU) is a powerhouse in the global dairy industry, with France, Germany, the
Netherlands, and Denmark as major contributors.
Locational Factors Responsible for the Success of the Dairy Industry in Europe:
❖ The temperate maritime climate (cool summers and mild winters) is ideal for grass cultivation. Ample year-round rainfall in NW Europe (British Type Climate) supports fodder crop production.
❖ Netherlands, Denmark, and Germany have fertile soils (rich in nutrients and good water-holding capacity) that are suitable for high-quality fodder crops.
❖ Flat or gently rolling terrain facilitates the mechanisation of dairy farming and efficient use of land
for pasture and fodder production. E.g. Northern Germany.
❖ The dairy-producing regions are located close to major urban centers, which reduces transportation
costs and helps maintain the freshness of dairy products.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• Diary Industry is not successful in Africa, because:
❖ Tropical climates with high temperatures and humidity reduce milk productivity.
❖ A uniform climate (lack of seasonal variation) poses challenges for fodder production and dairy
cattle breeding.
❖ The best milk-producing cattle breeds lack resistance to tropical diseases (foot-and-mouth disease,
East Coast fever, etc.) prevalent in Africa. While locust swarms in Africa devastate green pastures.
❖ Nutrient-deficient African grasslands limit milk yield potential.
❖ Low domestic demand for milk products (butter, cheese, etc.) in Africa due to poverty.
• New Zealand is renowned for its dairy industry, focusing on dairy exports, especially milk powder.
• Factors Behind New Zealand's Success in the Dairy Industry:
❖ Its temperate maritime climate is ideal for high-quality pasture production and allows year-round
grazing.
❖ Abundant rainfall and numerous rivers ensure a consistent water supply.
❖ Fertile volcanic and alluvial soils are well-suited for fodder crops.
❖ Flat to gently rolling terrain facilitates efficient land use, mechanisation, and transportation.
❖ As an island nation, it is free from many pests and animal diseases.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about major areas of the horticulture industry:
1. Olericulture focuses on the production of fruit and nut crops.
2. Pomology is concerned with the cultivation of vegetable food crops.
3. The ornamental horticulture deals with the growth and marketing of plants for their beauty.
How many of the statements given above are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Horticulture is the branch of agriculture that involves the cultivation of fruits, vegetables, nuts, seeds,
herbs, sprouts, algae, seaweeds, and non-food crops (grass and ornamental trees).
• It comprises three main areas: pomology, olericulture, and ornamental horticulture.
Statement 1 is incorrect
• Pomology involves planting, harvesting, storing, processing, and marketing fruit and nut crops.
• E.g., peaches, apples, pears, strawberries, almonds, pecans, and walnuts.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• Olericulture focuses on the production of vegetable food crops and encompasses planting, harvesting,
storing, processing, and marketing of vegetables.
• E.g., sweet corn, tomatoes, snap beans, and lettuce.
Statement 3 is correct
• The ornamental horticulture deals with the growth and marketing of plants for their beauty.
• It is divided into two categories: Floriculture and Landscape Horticulture.
• Floriculture:
❖ It involves the production and use of flowers, potted plants, and annual bedding plants, such as
poinsettias, carnations, philodendrons, and petunias.
• Landscape Horticulture:
❖ It encompasses designing, installing, and maintaining landscapes, including maples, oaks, forsythia,
honeysuckle, English ivy, peonies, and Kentucky bluegrass.

• The horticulture sector in India contributes approximately 33% (1/3rd) to GVA in agriculture.

with a smaller area (25.66 and 127. 6 million hectares for horticulture and food grains, respectively).

• Kolleru Lake is a lake in Andhra Pradesh that was designated as a Ramsar site in 2002.

• Once a lagoon, it is now several kilometres inland due to coastal emergence and delta formation.

• It is a permanent freshwater lake in a former channel of Brahmaputra located near Guwahati.

2024, the country has added 59 new wetlands to the list of Ramsar sites (as of August 2024 total 85

• Currently, Tamil Nadu harbours maximum number of Ramsar Sites (18 sites) followed by Uttar Pradesh (10 sites).

questions.question:
With reference to the National Family Health Survey (NFHS) of India, consider
the following statements:
1. It is conducted by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) every two years.
2. NFHS-5 data shows a decrease in the Total Fertility Rate.
3. The sex ratio of India as per NFHS-5 is 943 females per 1000 males.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) conducts the National Family Health Survey
(NFHS) approximately every three years.
• The survey provides high-quality, reliable, and comparable data on population dynamics and health
indicators. It also gathers data on emerging issues in health and family welfare.
• NFHS's primary aim is to assist policymakers and program-implementing agencies in setting benchmarks
for health and family welfare initiatives.
Statement 2 is correct
• Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is the average number of children a woman is expected to have during her
reproductive years.
• Below 2.1 indicates population decline potential. Above 2.1 suggests growth potential.
• NFHS-5 shows a decrease in the TFR from 2.2 in 2015-16 to 2.0 in 2019-21.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• Sex ratio is the proportion of males to females in a population is usually expressed as males per 100
females.
• According to NFHS-5, the sex ratio is 1020 females per 1,000 males (943 females per 1000 males as
per 2011 census), which is the highest sex ratio since the first NFHS survey in 1992.
• The sex ratio in rural India is 1,037, while in urban India, it is 985.

• In India, people migrate from rural to urban areas mainly due to push factors such as poverty, high
population pressure, lack of basic infrastructure, natural disasters, wars, and local conflicts.
• Pull factors like better opportunities, availability of regular work, relatively higher wages, better infrastructure, and accessibility attract people from rural areas to cities.

three percent for females.

most important cause in the rural areas of India except in Meghalaya, where the reverse is the case.

• Dibru-Saikhowa National Park:

questions.question:
Arrange the following iron ores in the order of their iron content from highest
to lowest:
1. Hematite
2. Magnetite
3. Limonite
4. Siderite
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Option (a) is correct
• Based on iron content Iron Ore can be divided into:
• Magnetite:
❖ Magnetite is black in colour. It is the best-quality iron ore, with excellent magnetic qualities and
more than 70% iron content.
❖ While hematite ore has high concentrations of hematite, magnetite ore has low concentrations of
magnetite, necessitating beneficiation (treated to improve its properties) for magnetite recovery.
❖ Steel and other end products derived from magnetite ore are typically higher in quality than those
from hematite ore due to magnetite's lower impurity levels.
❖ Magnetite with less iron content (25% to 30%) is known as taconite.
❖ Naturally magnetised magnetite is called lodestone.
• Hematite:
❖ Hematite, a reddish ore with naturally high iron content (60% to 70%).
❖ Because of its high iron concentration, it can be used in steel production without benefaction.
• Limonite:
❖ Limonite is an inferior iron ore that is yellowish with 40 to 60 % iron content.
❖ Limonite mines are open-cast mines; hence, mining is easy and cheap.
• Siderite:
❖ Siderite is a grey to brown inferior quality iron carbonate ore with less than 40% iron content.
❖ Due to its impurities, mining is economically unviable in many areas.
❖ One good quality is its lack of sulphur or phosphorus. Also, it is self-fluxioning due to lime presence

questions.question:

2. Raniganj

questions.explanation:

❖ The main coal fields are at Bokaro, Jharia, Deltenganj, Dhanbad, Auranga (Palamu), Giridh, Karanpura, Ramgarh, Hutar, Devgarh and Rajmahal.

coal (bituminous coking coal).

area.

❖ Raniganj Coalfield, West Bengal's most important coal reserve and mining area, extends across
Bardhman, Birbhum, Bankura, and Purulia districts, with a small portion also in Jharkhand.
❖ It is known for good quality coal with about 50 to 65% carbon content.
