❖ MP's main coal deposits lie in Singrauli, Muhpani, Satpura, Pench Kanhan, and Sohagpur.

field contains coking coal.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the characteristics of
Shale Gas and Tight Gas?
1. Shale gas consists mainly of methane with small amounts of ethane, propane, butane, and trace levels
of carbon dioxide, nitrogen, and hydrogen sulphide.
2. Shale gas is trapped in sandstone or limestone formations, whereas Tight Gas is found in shale rocks.
3. Tight Gas, like Shale Gas, requires massive hydraulic fracturing for extraction due to its low permeability.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Shale gas consists mainly of methane, with small amounts of ethane, propane, butane, & trace levels
of carbon dioxide, nitrogen, and hydrogen sulphide.
• Shales are fine-grained sedimentary rocks formed of organic-rich mud at the bottom of ancient seas.
• Subsequent sedimentation and the resultant heat and pressure transformed the mud into shale and
also produced natural gas from the organic matter contained in it.
• Over time, some gas migrated to nearby sandstones, forming conventional gas deposits, while the rest
stayed trapped in impermeable shale.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• The difference between shale gas and tight gas is that shale gas is trapped in shale rocks, while tight
gas is found trapped in sandstone or limestone formations with low permeability.
Statement 3 is correct
• Tight gas is natural gas produced from reservoir rocks of low permeability.
• Just like shale gas, it has to be extracted by massive hydraulic fracturing.

questions.question: Gibbsite, boehmite, and diaspore are related to which of the following minerals?
questions.explanation:
Option (a) is correct
• Bauxite, a sedimentary rock, is an ore of aluminium due to its high aluminium content.
• It is chemically reactive, undergoing processes like dissolution, hydration, and conversion to other aluminium compounds when exposed to suitable conditions.
• Bauxite mainly comprises aluminium hydroxide minerals such as gibbsite, boehmite, and diaspore,
along with iron oxides, clay minerals, and other minor components.
• Depending on impurities, it displays a variety of colours, such as brown, red, yellow, and white. Its texture ranges from dull and earthy to nodular.
Option (b) is incorrect
• Hematite, a reddish ore with naturally high iron content (60% to 70%).
• Because of its high iron concentration, it can be used in steel production without benefaction.
Option (c) is incorrect
• Galena (or lead glance), the natural mineral form of lead sulphide, is a principal ore of lead. It often
bears silver.
• It is found in veins in limestones, calcareous slates, and sandstones.
Option (d) is incorrect
• Magnetite is black in colour. It is the best-quality iron ore, with excellent magnetic qualities and more
than 70% iron content

questions.question: Which of the following minerals is commonly referred to as "fool's gold"?
questions.explanation:
Option (c) is correct
• Pyrite is a sulphide of iron [FeS₂ (Iron Disulfide)] that occurs in sedimentary rocks. It is a chief source
of sulphur. Its resemblance to gold led to its misleading nickname "fool's gold".
• Pyrite exhibits a brass-yellow colour, a brownish-black streak, and a metallic lustre.
• It was used in prehistoric times for fire-starting due to sparks produced when struck with steel.
• It is utilised in the production of sulphuric acid and serves as a direct soil conditioner.
• Pyrite includes sulphide materials like marcasite and pyrrhotite.

questions.question:
The primary purpose of the 'National River Conservation Plan' (NRCP) in India
is to:

questions.explanation:
The river cleaning programme in the country initiated with the launching of the Ganga Action Plan
(GAP) in 1985.
• The Ganga Action Plan was expanded to cover other rivers under National River Conservation Plan
(NRCP) in the year 1995.
• The objective of 'National River Conservation Plan' (NRCP) is to improve the water quality of the
rivers, which are the major water sources in the country, through the implementation of pollution abatement works.
• The pollution abatement works are implemented on a cost sharing basis between the Centre and State
Governments.
• The works include; collection, transportation and treatment of municipal sewage, River Front Development (RFD), Low-Cost Sanitation (LCS), Electric Crematoria, Improved Wood Based Crematoria etc.

questions.question:
With reference to marine deposits, consider the following statements:
1. Terrigenous deposits are primarily organic deposits that contain remnants of shells and skeletons.
2. Pelagic deposits originate from sources within the ocean itself.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Ocean deposits refer to the accumulation of unconsolidated sediments on the ocean floor. These deposits play a crucial role in understanding Earth's geological history and oceanic processes.
• They are broadly divided into two types —
❖ Terrigenous deposits (found mainly on the continental shelves and slopes)
❖ Pelagic deposits (found over deep-sea plains and the deeps)
Statement 1 is incorrect
• Terrigenous Deposits:
❖ They are mainly inorganic deposits of disintegrated rock material (due to weathering and water
erosion).
❖ The proportion of organic matter (in the form of shells, corals and skeletons) is quite negligible.
❖ They are found mainly on the continental shelves and slopes. Except for fine volcanic ash, little
terrigenous material is carried onto the sea surface.
❖ They are composed of sediments eroded from continents by rivers, glaciers, wind, and waves.
❖ They typically consist of a mixture of clay, silt, sand, and gravel. The composition and texture of the
deposits vary depending on the geological characteristics of the source region and the transportation
processes involved.
Statement 2 is correct
• Pelagic Deposits:
❖ Covering nearly 75% of the total sea floor, they consist of both organic and inorganic material.
❖ Organic material is in the form of liquid mud called ooze, which contains remnants of shells and
skeletons. Meanwhile, inorganic material is in the form of red clay, which is of volcanic origin.
❖ Red clay's chief constituents are silicon and aluminium dioxide. It is the most widely spread pelagic deposit on the sea floor.
❖ Pelagic deposits are found over deep-sea plains and abyssal plains in the deeper parts of the ocean.
❖ Unlike terrigenous deposits, pelagic deposits originate from sources within the ocean itself, such
as marine organisms, volcanic eruptions, and chemical precipitation.
❖ These deposits primarily consist of fine-grained particles, including clay minerals, siliceous ooze (composed of the remains of diatoms and radiolarians), and calcareous ooze (composed of the skeletal
remains of microscopic marine organisms like foraminifera and coccolithophores).
❖ Ocean circulation patterns, biological productivity, and water chemistry influence their composition
and distribution.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about hydrogen as a source of energy:
1. It is the most abundant chemical substance in the Earth's atmosphere, available freely in large quantities.
2. It is a zero-emission fuel that produces only water vapor as a byproduct when used as fuel.
3. It is considered an energy carrier rather than an energy source because it needs to be generated from
other substances.
4. Hydrogen fuel is more efficient than diesel or gas, as it can produce more energy per pound of fuel.
Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• Hydrogen is indeed the most abundant chemical substance in the universe but not freely available
in the Earth's atmosphere in large quantities. It must be produced from other compounds like water,
natural gas, or biomass.
• At standard temperature and pressure, hydrogen is a non-toxic, odourless, tasteless, colourless, and
highly combustible diatomic gas with the molecular formula H2.
Statement 2 is correct
• Hydrogen is a clean source of energy and is known as a zero-emission fuel because it only produces
water vapor when used.
Statement 3 is correct
• Hydrogen is considered an energy carrier because it must be produced using other energy sources,
similar to electricity.
• Energy carriers allow the transport of energy from one place to another.
• To produce hydrogen, the electrolysis process is used for splitting the components of water into hydrogen and oxygen.
• Electrolysis is the process by which an electric current is passed through a substance to effect a chemical
change.
Statement 4 is correct
• Hydrogen is more fuel-efficient than traditional fossil fuels like diesel or gas, producing more energy
per unit weight.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the generations of biofuels:
1. First-generation biofuels are produced from non-food crops, which avoids the "fuel vs. food" debate.
2. Second-generation biofuels are derived from food crops like wheat and sugar.
3. Third-generation biofuels are designed to be carbon-negative, capturing and storing more carbon
dioxide than they emit.
4. Fourth-generation biofuels utilize algae as a feedstock, but they are only carbon-neutral, with no net
effect on carbon dioxide levels.
How many of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• The First-Generation biofuels are produced directly from food crops by abstracting the oils for use in
biodiesel or producing bioethanol through conventional methods like fermentation.
• Crops such as wheat and sugar are the most widely used feedstock for bioethanol, while rapeseed oil
has proved highly effective for use in biodiesel.
• First-generation biofuels have a number of problems:
❖ These biofuels can produce Negative Net energy gains, releasing more carbon in their production
than their feedstock captures in their growth.
❖ The most contentious issue is ‘fuel vs food’.
❖ Biofuels from food grains have been blamed for the increase in food prices over the last couple of
years.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• The 2G biofuels are produced from non-food crops such as wood, organic waste, food crop waste
and specific biomass crops, therefore eliminating the main problem with first-generation biofuels.
• They are also aimed at being more cost-competitive in relation to existing fossil fuels.
• Life cycle assessments of second-generation biofuels have also indicated that they will increase Positive
net energy gains, overcoming another of the main limitations of first-generation biofuels.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• The Third Generation of biofuels takes advantage of specially engineered energy crops such as algae.
• The algae are cultured to act as a low-cost, high-energy, and entirely renewable feedstock.
• It is predicted that algae will have the potential to produce more energy per acre than conventional crops.
• Algae can also be grown using land and water unsuitable for food production.
• A further benefit of algae-based biofuels is that the fuel can be manufactured into a wide range of
fuels, such as diesel, petrol, and jet fuel.
• It is potentially carbon neutral (the same amount of carbon is absorbed and emitted).
Statement 4 is incorrect
• The Fourth Generation of biofuels is aimed at not only producing sustainable energy but also a way of
capturing and storing CO2.
• Biomass materials, which have absorbed CO2 while growing, are converted into fuel using the same processes as second-generation biofuels.
• This process differs from second and third-generation production as at all stages of production, the carbon dioxide is captured using processes such as oxy-fuel combustion.
• The carbon dioxide can then be geo-sequestered by storing it in old oil and gas fields or saline aquifers.
• This carbon capture makes 4th generation biofuel production carbon-negative rather than simply carbon neutral, as it locks away more carbon than it produces.
• This system not only captures and stores carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, but it also reduces CO2
emissions by replacing fossil fuels.

port and well protected from the fury of sea waves vessels. It is India's largest port
in terms of size and shipping traffic. Which of the following ports matches this description?
questions.explanation:
Mumbai Port is situated in Thane Creek on the lee side of Salsette/Mumbai Island. It is all-weather
natural port and well protected from the fury of sea waves.
• Since the opening of the Suez Canal in 1869, Mumbai Port became India's principal gateway, playing a
pivotal role in the country's trade and commerce development.
• It is India's largest port in terms of size and shipping traffic.
• The major export items are textiles, raw cotton, etc.,
• The primary imports are petroleum, petroleum products, fertilisers, chemicals, paper, and raw cotton.
Option (a) is incorrect
• Jawaharlal Nehru Port (or Nhava Sheva) is a prominent seaport in Navi Mumbai, Maharashtra. It is
the largest public container port in India.
• It has developed a multi-product Special Economic Zone on its owned freehold land to attract international capital and global manufacturing giants.
• The key exports include textiles, sporting goods, carpets, textile machinery, boneless meat, as well as
chemicals and pharmaceuticals.
• The significant imports encompass chemicals, machinery, plastics, electrical machinery, vegetable oils,
Aluminum, and other non-ferrous metals.
• The JNPA's hinterland covers a large part of India, including the states of Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh,
Gujarat, Karnataka, and most of North India.
Option (c) is incorrect
• Vadhavan Port is an ‘All Weather, All Cargo’ satellite port that can handle deep draft ships and larger
vessels. The port will be located close to the JNPT in Uran, Navi Mumbai.
• This satellite port helps overcome issues such as limited land availability and draft adequacy, which
is the depth of water to which a ship sinks according to its load.
• It will be India’s 13th major port once completed. It is expected to handle spillovers in container vessel
traffic at the Jawaharlal Nehru Port, India’s top container port.
• The Vadhavan port will be developed on a “landlord model,” in which the government owns the port's
infrastructure and leases it to private companies. Private developers undertake all business activities
under PPP mode.
Option (d) is incorrect
• Mundra Port is the largest private port and the largest container port in India. It is located on the
north shores of the Gulf of Kutch, Gujarat.
• This deep-draft, all-weather port is the largest coal import terminal in India. It is also a special economic zone (SEZ).

questions.question:
With reference to Inland Water Transport (IWT) in India, consider the following
statements:
1. IWT is considered a less polluting but more expensive mode of transport compared to rail and road.
2. The Inland Waterways Authority of India is a statutory body established to develop, maintain, and
regulate national waterways in the country.
Which of the statements given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• Inland Water Transport (IWT) is considered an environmentally friendly and less polluting mode of
transport compared to rail and road.
• Historically, IWT was a primary mode of transport before the rise of railways, but it has faced competition
from road and rail transport.
• Additionally, IWT is cost-effective for transporting bulk cargo like coal, fly ash, and iron ore.
Statement 2 is correct
• The Inland Waterways Authority of India (IWAI) is a statutory body established under the Inland
Waterways Authority of India Act, 1985.
• The IWAI's headquarters is located in Noida.
• It is responsible for the development, maintenance, and regulation of national waterways in the
country.

questions.question:
Consider the following Ports in India:

2. Kochi Port
3. Vizhinjam International Seaport
4. Colachel Seaport
5. Marmagao Port
How many of the above-mentioned Mega ports are planned under Sagarmala project?
questions.explanation:
The Sagarmala Project is a flagship Central Sector Scheme of the Ministry of Ports, Shipping and
Waterways (MoPSW).
• It aims to foster port-led development in India by leveraging its 7,500 km coastline, 14,500 km of navigable waterways, and strategic global maritime position.
• The Union Cabinet approved the concept of Sagarmala in 2015. The vision is to reduce domestic and
EXIM cargo logistics costs with optimised infrastructure investment.
• The five pillars of the Sagarmala Project are:
❖ Port modernisation & new port development
❖ Port connectivity enhancement
❖ Port-led industrialisation
❖ Coastal community development
❖ Coastal shipping and Inland water transport
• Projects under Sagarmala are implemented by relevant Major Ports, Central Ministries, State Maritime
Boards, State Governments, and other agencies.
Options 1, 3 and 4 are correct, 2 and 5 are incorrect
• Six Megaports planned under Sagarmala Project are:
❖ Kerala: The Vizhinjam International Seaport is located in Vizhinjam.
❖ Tamil Nadu: The Colachel Seaport is situated in Colachel.
❖ Maharashtra: Vadhavan Port, located near Dahanu.
❖ Karnataka: The Tadadi Port in Tadadi.
❖ Andhra Pradesh: Machilipatnam Port, located in Machilipatnam.
❖ West Bengal: The Sagar Island Port on Sagar Island.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about Inland Water Transport (IWT) in India:

Which one of the following is correct in respect of the above statements?

options.text: ) Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct, and Statement-II is the correct explanation for Statement-I.

Statement-I
Statement-I is correct, but Statement-II is incorrect.

questions.explanation:

• The modal share of waterways in India’s freight movement is about 2%, whereas the corresponding
figure is 4% for USA, 14% for China, 48% for Vietnam, and 49% for Netherlands.

• It is considered an environmentally friendly and less pollutant mode of transport compared to rail and
road.
• Bulk cargo such as coal, fly ash, and iron ore was found to be economical and cost-effective for transportation through IWT.

questions.question:
With reference to the types of ports, consider the following statements:
1. A satellite port generally acts as an intermediate stop for a ship on its scheduled journey for unloading
and loading cargo.
2. A tidal port is one in which the level of water within the port varies with the change in the level of
water in the oceans.
3. A port of call is a port, either created or pre-existing, in a community near a port that is nearing
capacity and requires relief from the current heavy loads.
Which of the statements given above are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• A satellite port is a port created or pre-existing near a primary port that is nearing capacity and requires relief from heavy cargo loads. It is not an intermediate stop for ships.
Statement 2 is correct
• A tidal port experiences water level variations in sync with the ocean's tides and is typically located
near coastal areas.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• A port of call is an intermediate stop on a ship's journey for loading/unloading cargo, refueling, or
maintenance, not a port created to relieve heavy loads from another port.

questions.question:

questions.explanation:

• Air transport in India made a beginning in 1911 when airmail operation commenced over a small distance of 10 km between Allahabad and Naini.

Jaipur, Calicut, Nagpur, Coimbatore, Cochin, Lucknow, Pune, Chandigarh, Mangaluru, Vishakhapatnam,

questions.question:
With reference to the Indian pharmaceutical industry, consider the following
statements:

2. Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in India's pharmaceutical sector allows for 100% investment under
the automatic route for both greenfield and brownfield pharmaceuticals.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• The Indian pharmaceutical industry holds a significant position in the global market, with its major
segments including generic drugs, over the counter (OTC) medicines, bulk drugs, vaccines, contract research and manufacturing, biosimilars, and biologics.
• The nation is the largest provider of generic medicines globally, occupying a 20% share in global
supply by volume, and is the leading vaccine manufacturer globally.
• The country is a major supplier of low-cost vaccines, accounting for 60% of global vaccine production. India meets up to 70% of the World Health Organization's (WHO) demand for DPT and BCG vaccines, and 90% of the demand for measles vaccines.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• While 100% FDI is allowed in the pharmaceutical sector in India, the conditions differ based on the
type of investment:

route.

under the automatic route. For any investment beyond 74%, government approval is required.

questions.question:

realising this.
• The Indian space sector is recognised for building cost-effective satellites with launch of the Mars
probes successfully at first attempt and taking hundreds of foreign satellites to space.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding water consumption:
1. Amongst the water-intensive industries, thermal power plants are the highest consumer of water.
2. Globally, India is the largest consumer of water.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Of the total water use by the industry, thermal power plants are the biggest users of water and account
for 88% of the total industrial water use. They are followed by engineering (5.05%) pulp & paper
(2.26%) and textiles (2.07%) industries.
• Industries use water for cooling and cleaning. Cooling prevents equipment, machinery, and processes
from overheating and getting damaged.
• Overall, two of the most water consuming sectors of the economy are agriculture and thermoelectric
power, although other industries may use a significant proportion of public water supplies in some areas.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• Amongst the top 10 countries that use the most water, China is considered as the largest consumer of
water 362 trillion gallons followed by USA -216 trillion gallons, Brazil – 95 trillion gallons, Russia – 71
trillion gallons, Mexico – 53 trillion gallons, India – 30 trillion gallons, England – 20 trillion gallons, France
– 20 trillion gallons, Canada – 19 trillion gallons, Australia – 12 trillion gallons
• India stands at 6th position with regard to water consumption.
• With a population of 1.1 billion people, India uses the least amount of water per person of all the
countries on the list.
• With a population of 300 million people, the United States uses the most water per person of all the
countries on the list.

questions.question:
Regarding Livestock Census and Integrated Sample Survey, consider the following statements:
1. The livestock census and integrated sample survey is a central sector scheme to promote missions
like Rashtriya Gokul Mission.
2. The livestock census component under the scheme is conducted every 4 years.
3. In the Integrated Sample Survey component, four major livestock products (MLPs) like Milk, Egg, Meat
and Wool are estimated both at National and State level.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statements 1 and 2 are incorrect
• The Animal Husbandry Statistics (AHS) Division of Department of Animal Husbandry & Dairying
(DAHD) is entrusted with the generation of Animal Husbandry Statistics through the Centrally Sponsored Scheme “Livestock Census and Integrated Sample Survey" under the development programmes
category with two components, (i) Livestock Census (LC) & (ii) Integrated Sample Survey (ISS).
• The scheme is being implemented by the Department of Animal Husbandry and Dairying through
State Animal Husbandry Departments.
• Department of Animal Husbandry conducts livestock Census every 5 year since 1919-20.
• The 20th Livestock Census: data collection started in 2018-Oct. data released in 2019.
• India has the world's largest livestock population
Statement 3 is correct
• Under this scheme, the quantum of four major livestock products (MLPs) like Milk, Egg, Meat and
Wool is estimated based on the annual sample survey namely “Integrated Sample Survey” both at
National and State level.
• This has been an essential survey to measure the contribution of livestock sector and its products in the
total economy.
• The survey is carried out in the entire country covering 36 States/UTs both in rural and urban areas.
• The survey period is from March to February and the entire period of one year is divided into three
seasons namely summer, rainy and winter having four months period each.
• This helps in bringing up progressive estimates of aggregates and also takes care of seasonality if any in
the characters under study.
• At present, in this survey the traditional approach of using paper schedules for filling-in information at
the field level is replaced by the Computer Assisted Personal Interviewing (CAPI) method. The data is
being directly entered into the tablets by the field workers using a specialised software developed by the
department called “eLISS”

questions.question:

time it is an instrument of livelihood for a large section of economically backward population of the

• Fishery sector occupies an important place in the socio-economic development of the country. "Fisheries
is a fast-growing sector in India, which provides nutrition and food security to a large population of the
country besides providing income and employment to more than 28 million people.
• Fisheries sector has been recognized as a ‘Sunrise Sector’ and has demonstrated an outstanding double-digit average annual growth of 10.87% since 2014-15.

questions.question: Which of the following regions of India is known for its production of saffron?
questions.explanation:
Option (a) is correct and all other options are incorrect
• Saffron cultivation is typical in the Kashmir region. This plant is mentioned in the 5th century B.C in
Kashmiri records and is still part of the agricultural economy. Known over the world, Saffron became a
cash crop for farmers resulting of a long traditional heritage. Pampore, also known as the Saffron Town
of Kashmir, is famous for its saffron cultivation. The town's climatic conditions and soil make it an ideal
location for producing high-quality saffron, making Pampore the main saffron cultivation area in the
region.
• The Konkan region is famous for its cultivation of mangoes, cashews, coconut, and spices like chillies,
turmeric, and cardamom.
• In the coromandel region, agriculture is the mainstay of the coastal economy. Rice, pulses (legumes),
sugarcane, cotton, and peanuts (groundnuts) are grown. Bananas and betel nuts are grown together with
rice in the low-rainfall region of the interior. There are casuarina and coconut plantations along the coast.
• The cultivation of subsistence cereals including millets, oilseeds, and pulses is the major occupation and
source of livelihood of people of the Garhwal region.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
1. India has the 4th largest railway system globally, following the US, Russia, and China.
2. Transcontinental railways are constructed primarily for economic and political reasons to facilitate
long runs across continents.
3. The Trans-Siberian Railway runs from St. Petersburg in the west to Vladivostok on the Pacific Coast
and is the longest double-tracked and electrified transcontinental railway in the world.
4. Europe has one of the sparse rail networks in the world, with freight transport being more important
than passenger transport.
How many of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• India has the 4th largest railway system globally, following the US, Russia, and China.
• The total length of railway tracks including broad gauge, metre gauge and narrow gauge as on 31.03.
2023 is 1,32,310 kms and total length of double line track is 26,578 kms.
Statement 2 is correct
• Trans-continental railways run across the continent and link its two ends.
• They were constructed for economic and political reasons to facilitate long runs in different directions.
Statement 3 is correct
• The Trans-Siberian Railway runs from St. Petersburg in the west to Vladivostok on the Pacific Coast.

Irkutsk, a fur centre, are on the route.

has helped open up the Asian region to West European markets.

highest densities in the world. Passenger transport is more important than freight in many of these
countries.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the Border Roads Organisation
(BRO):

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding satellite systems in India:
1. The Indian National Satellite (INSAT) system is exclusively used for meteorological observations.
2. The Indian Remote Sensing (IRS) satellites provide data for weather monitoring, natural disaster management, and agriculture, among other purposes.
3. The GSAT system is responsible for the expansion of India's broadcasting and communication services.
Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect, and Statement 3 is correct
• The INSAT system is a multi-purpose satellite system used not only for meteorological observations
but also for telecommunications, TV broadcasting, and other services.
• Over the last twenty-five years, the Indian National Satellite (INSAT) and GSAT systems have brought
about a revolution in various sectors, including telecommunications, TV broadcasting, DTH services,
business communications, and rural area connectivity.
• Established in 1983, the Indian National Satellite (INSAT) is a multi-purpose satellite system for telecommunication, meteorological observation, and various other data and programs.
• It is one of the largest domestic communication satellite systems in the Asia-Pacific region.
• Nine operational communication satellites are placed in Geostationary orbit.
• The IRS satellite system became operational after the launch of IRS-IA in 1988 in Russia.
• The National Remote Sensing Centre (NRSC) at Hyderabad provides facilities for data acquisition and
processing.
• The expansion of broadcasting and communication services in the country is done through the GSAT
system, which made India the largest domestic communication satellite system in the world.
Statement 2 is correct
• IRS satellites are used for multiple purposes including weather monitoring, disaster management, and
agriculture.
• The National Natural Resources Management System (NNRMS) oversees Indian Earth Observation
activities.
• The Indian Earth Observation (EO) system operates a constellation of remote sensing satellites, including IRS and INSAT systems. IRS satellites provide data at different spatial, spectral, and temporal resolutions.
• Indian Remote Sensing satellites (IRS) are equipped with sensors that can capture Earth's images and
data from space.
• These satellites detect various types of radiation emitted or reflected from the Earth's surface.
• They serve multiple purposes, including weather monitoring, natural disaster monitoring, agriculture, forestry, and land-based activities.
• The launch of India’s first civilian IRS-1A spacecraft in March 1988 marked the beginning of the Indian
Space Programme's successful journey.

questions.question: PM MITRA Park is related to:

questions.question:
Arrange the following iron and steel plants from south to north direction
1. Bokaro
2. Bhadravati
3. Rourkela
4. Bhilai
5. Durgpur
Select the correct answer using the code given below
questions.explanation:
Three new integrated steel plants were established after independence with foreign collaboration during
the Second Five-Year Plan (1956-61): Rourkela, Bhilai, and Durgpur.
• Rourkela Steel Plant:
❖ In 1973, the Steel Authority of India Limited (SAIL) was formed to manage these plants.
❖ The Rourkela Steel Plant, established in collaboration with Germany, is strategically located in the
Sundargarh district of Odisha.
❖ It benefits from coal supply from Jharia, iron ore from Sundargarh and Kendujhar, and power from
the Hirakud project.
❖ Water is sourced from the Koel and Sankh Rivers.
• Bhilai Steel Plant:
❖ It was established with Russian collaboration in the Durg district of Chhattisgarh.
❖ It is situated on the Kolkata-Mumbai railway route.
❖ Iron ore is sourced from the Dalli-Rajhara mine, while coal comes from the Korba and Kargali coal
fields. Water is supplied from the Tandula dam, and the Korba Thermal Power Station supplies power.
• Durgpur Steel Plant:
❖ It is established in collaboration with the UK government and is situated on the main Kolkata-Delhi
railway route in West Bengal.
❖ The plant, located in the Raniganj and Jharia coal belt, receives iron ore from Noamundi.
❖ It obtains hydel power and water from the Damodar Valley Corporation (DVC).
• Bokaro Steel Plant:
❖ It is located in the Hazaribagh district of Jharkhand.
❖ It is the fourth integrated plant in the Public Sector made with the collaboration of the Soviet Union.
❖ It was originally incorporated as a limited company in January 1964, and was later merged with SAIL,
first as a subsidiary and then as a unit, through the Public Sector Iron & Steel Companies (Restructuring & Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1978.
• Bhadravati or Visvesvaraya Steel Plant:
❖ It is India's third integrated steel plant, initially named Mysore Wood Distillation & Iron Works.
❖ Located near the iron ore-rich Kemangundi area of the Bababudan hills, it also has local access to
limestone and manganese.
❖ The Bhadravathi River supplies water to the plant.
❖ The region lacks coal. So, until 1951, charcoal obtained by burning wood from nearby forests served
as fuel. Later, electric furnaces powered by hydroelectricity from the Jog Falls (Sharavati) hydel
power project were installed.

questions.question:
Which of the following are the major factors determining the location of the
sugar industry?
1. Transportation
2. Water
3. Labour
4. Capital
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Sugarcane is a highly perishable and weight-losing raw material. Due to this, it is expensive to
transport sugarcane over long distances. Therefore, sugar mills are located close to cane-growing areas.
• Sugarcane is a water-intensive crop with a crop season of 12 to 18 months. Hence the availability of
water year-round is a critical factor for its cultivation.
• Sugarcane harvesting occurs seasonally, and the crushing season varies from 4 to 8 months. Hence, seasonal labour is critical for both harvesting and processing.
• Sugarcane processing is a capital-intensive industry. Financial services are critical for the industry to
remain competitive.

questions.question:
Consider the following techniques used in Agriculture:
1. Soil aeration
2. Deep ploughing
3. Minimal watering
4. Use of vermicompost
5. Intercropping
6. Topsoil mulching
How many of the factors above given is/are not associated with Zero-Budget Natural Farming?
questions.explanation:
India introduced Zero-Budget Natural Farming (ZBNF) in its Budget 2019-20.
• It was first propagated by Subhash Palekar (who was conferred with Padma Shri in 2016) as a movement
for farmers who were in debt due to the Green Revolution.
• ZBNF is neither chemical-loaded nor organic.
• It seeks to reduce input costs to ZERO by avoiding chemical and manufactured inputs and encouraging
farmers to rely upon natural products available locally.
• It is considered a 'zero budget' because there is not much need to spend money on inputs and the
costs of raising the main crop are offset by the income that farmers earn from intercrops.
Options 1, 3, 5 and 6 are associated
• Components of ZBNF include:
❖ Soil aeration
❖ Minimal watering (saves electricity),
❖ Intercropping and
❖ Bunds and
❖ Topsoil mulching
Options 2 and 4 are not associated
• ZBNF discourages intensive irrigation and deep ploughing.
• It opposes the use of vermicompost.
• Instead, it recommends the revival of local deep soil earthworms through increased organic matter.
• In ZBNF, chemical fertilisers, and pesticides make way for locally available cow dung, cow urine, jaggery, etc., and treat seeds with natural ingredients made on the farm by the farmer himself.
• ZBNF promotes the application of
❖ Jivamrita/jeevamrutha: it is a fermented microbial culture. It provides nutrients and promotes the
activity of microorganisms and earthworms in the soil. It also helps to prevent fungal and bacterial
plant diseases.
❖ Bijamrita: Bijamrita effectively protects young roots from fungus and soil-borne and seed-borne
diseases. Jeevamrutha and Bijamrita are prepared from a mixture of desi cow dung and urine, jaggery, etc.
❖ Acchadana/Mulching: a protective biomass layer on soil.
❖ Whapasa/Moisture: Whapasa is the condition where there are both air molecules and water molecules present in the soil. It involves reducing irrigation, irrigating only at noon in alternate furrows.
• Also, ZBNF includes three methods of insect and pest management: Agniastra, Brahmastra, and Neemastra (preparations using cow urine, cow dung, tobacco, fruits, green chilli, garlic, and neem).

questions.question: Which of the following is a key principle of Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM)?

options.text: Development of water resources in isolation
Coordination among different sectors and stakeholders
Prioritization of industrial water use over agricultural use

questions.explanation:
Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM) is a process that promotes the coordinated development and management of water, land and related resources in order to maximize economic
and social welfare in an equitable manner without compromising the sustainability of vital ecosystems.
• IWRM is a cross-sectoral policy approach designed to replace the traditional, fragmented sectoral approach to water resources and management that has led to poor services and unsustainable resource
use.
• Integrated Water Resources Management is based on the understanding that water resources are an
integral component of the ecosystem, a natural resource, and a social and economic good.
• The basis of IWRM is that the many different uses of finite water resources are interdependent.
• High irrigation demands and polluted drainage flows from agriculture, for example, mean less freshwater
for drinking or industrial use; contaminated municipal and industrial wastewater pollutes rivers and
threatens ecosystems; if water has to be left in a river to protect fisheries and ecosystems (environmental
flows), less can be diverted to grow crops.
• There are plenty of other examples of the basic theme that unregulated use of scarce water resources is
wasteful and inherently unsustainable.

questions.question:
How many of the following are natural lakes?
1. Kodaikanal
2. Kolleru
3. Lonar
4. Kanwar Lake
5. Chilika Lake
6. Vembanad Lake
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Kodaikanal lake is a manmade lake all other lakes are natural.
• Kodaikanal Lake, also known as Kodai Lake, is a manmade lake located in the Kodaikanal city in Dindigul
district in Tamil Nadu.
• Kolleru Lake is located in the state of Andhra Pradesh in southern India. It's situated between the Godavari and Krishna River deltas, close to the city of Eluru.
• Lonar Lake, also known as Lonar crater, is a saline, soda lake in Maharashtra. It is a notified National
Geo-heritage Monument.
• The Kanwar Taal or Kabar Taal Lake or Kabartal Wetland located in Begusarai district of Bihar, India, is
Asia's largest freshwater oxbow lake.
• Chilika Lake is the largest brackish water lagoon in Asia and second largest coastal lagoon in the
world, located in Odisha state on the east coast of India, at the mouth of the Daya River, flowing into
the Bay of Bengal. It has been listed as a tentative UNESCO World Heritage site.
• Vembanad is the longest lake in India, as well as the largest in the state of Kerala.

questions.question:
With reference to offshore wind energy, consider the following statements:
1. The National Offshore Wind Energy Policy of 2015 empowers the Ministry of New and Renewable
Energy (MNRE) to regulate and manage offshore wind energy projects within India’s entire Exclusive
Economic Zone (EEZ).
2. India’s offshore wind energy potential is projected to be 140 GW by 2050, with a significant portion
of this potential located off the coast of Gujarat and Tamil Nadu.
3. Offshore wind energy is typically more cost-effective than onshore wind energy, as it avoids land
acquisition challenges and benefits from lower tariffs.
How many of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• As per the policy, Ministry of New and Renewable Energy act as the nodal Ministry for development
of Offshore Wind Energy in India and work in close coordination with other government entities for
Development and Use of Maritime Space within the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of the country and
shall be responsible for overall monitoring of offshore wind energy development in the country.
• National Institute of Wind Energy (NIWE), Chennai is the nodal agency to carryout resource assessment, surveys and studies in EEZ, demarcate blocks and facilitate developers for setting up offshore
wind energy farms.
Statement 2 is correct
• India’s offshore wind energy potential is indeed projected to be 140 GW by 2050, with significant potential off the Gujarat and Tamil Nadu coasts.
• The onshore wind energy potential estimated by the National Institute of Wind Energy (NIWE) stands
at 300 GW at 100 m hub height.
• However, many onshore wind energy projects are adversely affected due to land acquisition issues. Offshore wind energy does not have that constraint.
• The tariff discovered through e-auction started moving upwards on account of the exhaustion of best
wind sites. Hence, offshore wind can be seen as a viable future option.
• Onshore wind is more intermittent than offshore. At sea, winds are free from any obstruction and
thus, flow more smoothly, with higher speed.
• With onshore wind, utilisation is at best 35%, but with offshore, it could be up to 50-55% due to stronger
winds at sea.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• Offshore wind energy is generally more expensive than onshore wind due to higher installation and
maintenance costs, despite not having land acquisition issues.
• Offshore wind turbines require longer blades, and transporting them over long distances is not viable.
• Ports in TN and Gujarat would have to be developed such that blades can be manufactured near the
closest port from the offshore site.
• Offshore plants have significant challenges, including subsea cabling, turbine foundation, installation of
turbines including logistics, grid interconnection and operation, development of transmission infrastructure and coastal security during the construction and operation period.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the PM-KUSUM scheme:
1. It was launched by the Ministry of Power which aims to support both off-grid and grid-connected
solar-powered systems for agriculture.
2. The scheme includes components related to the installation of LED lighting systems in urban areas.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• PM-KUSUM (Pradhan Mantri Kisan Urja Suraksha evam Utthaan Mahabhiyan) was launched in 2019 by
the Ministry of New and Renewable Energy (MNRE).
• It supports the installation of both off-grid and grid-connected solar-powered systems for agriculture
and reduce dependence on the grid, in grid-connected areas.
• PM-KUSUM Scheme is for de-dieselisation of farm sector and enhancing the income of farmers.
• Under the Scheme, central government subsidy upto 30% or 50% of the total cost is given for the installation of standalone solar pumps and also for the solarization of existing grid-connected agricultural
pumps.
• Further, farmers can also install grid-connected solar power plants up to 2MW under the Scheme on
their barren/fallow land and sell electricity to local DISCOM at a tariff determined by state regulator.
• This scheme is being implemented by the designated departments of the State Government.
• It consists of three components:
❖ Component A: Setting up of 10,000 MW of Decentralized Ground/ Stilt Mounted Grid Connected
Solar or other Renewable Energy based Power Plants by the farmers on their land.
❖ Component B: Installation of 14 Lakh Stand-alone Solar Agriculture Pumps.
❖ Component C: Solarisation of 35 Lakh Grid Connected Agriculture Pumps including Feeder Level
Solarization.
• All three components of the scheme aim to add Solar capacity of about 34,800 MW by March 2026 with
the total Central Financial support of ₹ 34,422 crore.
• Progress of PM-KUSUM scheme as of December 2023.
• Besides reducing emissions, the scheme aims to address challenges of irrigation supply, subsidy burden
on discoms (~Rs 50,000 crores) and farmer income (sale of surplus).
Statement 2 is incorrect
• The PM-KUSUM scheme does not include components related to LED lighting systems in urban areas; its focus is on solar-powered systems for agriculture.

questions.question:
With reference to the International Solar Alliance (ISA), consider the following
statements:
1. It is an intergovernmental organization established to promote efficient solar energy consumption
and reduce reliance on fossil fuels.
2. It was launched by India and Germany during the 2015 UNFCCC (COP21, Paris) summit, and its headquarters is in Gurugram, India.
3. Membership in the ISA is restricted only to countries located between the Tropic of Cancer and the
Tropic of Capricorn.
4. The ISA aims to mobilize investments of more than USD 1 trillion by 2030 and create a World Solar
Bank with an authorized capital of $15 billion.
How many of the statements given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• ISA, or the International Agency for Solar Policy and Application (IASPA), is a treaty-based intergovernmental organisation.
• Its objective is to work for efficient consumption of solar energy to reduce dependence on fossil fuels.
• ISA was proposed by PM Modi at the India Africa Summit ahead of the Paris Summit.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• While ISA was launched during the 2015 UNFCCC (COP21, Paris) summit, it was actually initiated by
India and France, not Germany.
• It is headquartered in Gurugram, India.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• Although ISA primarily targets countries located between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn, countries outside this region can also join the alliance but do not have voting rights.
• ISA will not duplicate or replicate the efforts that others are currently engaged in but will establish
networks, develop synergies with them, and supplement their efforts in a sustainable manner.
• To deploy cost-effective solutions, especially in the Least Developed Countries (LDCs) and the Small
Island Developing States (SIDS), ISA is partnering with multilateral development banks (MDBs), development financial institutions (DFIs), and other international institutions such as:
❖ International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA),
❖ Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Partnership (REEEP),
❖ International Energy Agency (IEA),
❖ Renewable Energy Policy Network for the 21st Century (REN21),
❖ United Nations bodies, bilateral organisations etc.
Statement 4 is correct
• The ISA has set ambitious goals, including mobilizing more than USD 1 trillion in investments by 2030
and creating a World Solar Bank with an authorized capital of $15 billion.
• Objectives of the ISA includes:
❖ To mobilise investments of more than USD 1000 billion (1 trillion USD) by 2030.
❖ To take coordinated action for promoting solar finance, solar technologies, R&D, capacity building
etc.
❖ Reduce the cost of finance to increase investments in solar energy in member countries.
❖ Scale-up applications of solar technologies in member countries.
❖ Facilitate collaborative R&D activities in solar energy technologies among member countries.
❖ Promote a common cyber platform for cooperation and exchange of ideas among member countries.
❖ ISA aims to create a World Solar Bank with an authorised capital of $15 billion to fund projects

questions.question:
With reference the ports in India, consider the following Information:
Ports- Location- Significance
1. Kolkata Port- Hugli River- Oldest major port
2. V.O. Chidambaram Port -Gulf of Mannar- Largest Port on the East Coast
3. Kandla Port -Gulf of Kutch- Deepest Port
In how many of the above rows is the given information correctly matched?
questions.explanation:
Information 1 is correct
• Kolkata Port (KoPT), on the left bank of the Hugli River, is the first major and the only riverine port in
India.
• It is officially known as the Syama Prasad Mookerjee Port Trust of Kolkata.
• It is the oldest port among the major ports of India.
• It is confronted with the problem of silt accumulation in the Hugli River. The estuary's dynamic nature
results in frequent shifting of the navigation channels.
• The major export items are iron ore, leather, cotton textiles, etc.
• The major import items are wheat, raw cotton, iron and steel, etc
Information 2 is incorrect
• Tuticorin Port (TPT) is officially known as the V.O. Chidambaram Port. It is located strategically close
to the East-West International Sea routes.
• Located in the Gulf of Mannar, sheltered by Sri Lanka to the southeast and India to the west, it is protected from storms and cyclonic winds.
• This artificial port is the fourth-largest container terminal in India. It is Tamil Nadu’s third international
port and second-largest all-weather port.
• Chennai port is the largest port on the eastern coast, not Tuticorin port.
• Its principal exports include general cargo, sugar, granite, and limonite ore. Major imports include coal,
cement, fertilisers, rock phosphate, petroleum products, petroleum coke, and edible oils.
Information 3 is incorrect
• Kandla Port (or Deendayal Port) is located on the Gulf of Kutch in Gujarat. It was constructed in the
1950s as the chief seaport serving western India after the partition.
• It is a natural harbour in the Kutch district near the city of Gandhidham. It has a modern container
terminal and a dry dock facility.
• It is the largest public port based on the volume of cargo handled. But the deepest port is Gangavaram Port (Vishakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh).
• The major import items of this port are petroleum, chemicals, steel, iron machinery, etc. The major exports
from this port are grains, processed food products, textiles, etc.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
1. Statement – I: State governments have the power to frame rules to prevent illegal mining of minor
minerals.
2. Statement – II: Sand is a 'minor mineral' according to the prevailing law in the country.
Which one of the following is correct in respect of the above statements?

options.text: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct, and Statement II is the correct explanation for Statement I.

Both Statement I and Statement II are correct, but Statement II is not the correct explanation for
Statement I.
Statement I is correct, but Statement II is not correct
Statement I is not correct, but Statement II is correct.

questions.explanation:
Both Statement I and Statement II are correct, and Statement II is the correct explanation for Statement
I
• Sand comes within the definition of “minor minerals” under the Mines and Minerals (Development
and Regulation) Act of 1957 (Mines Act).
• Any mining operations, reconnaissance, or prospecting of sand can only be undertaken with prior permission or license from the government.
• Since minor minerals fall under the legislative purview of the state governments, the licensing for sand
mining is regulated by the states, under their respective “minor mineral concession rules” framed under
the Mines Act.
• Section 15 of the MMDR Act empowers state governments to make rules for regulating the grant of
mineral concessions in respect of minor minerals and for purposes connected therewith.

questions.question:
With reference to the schemes related to road transport, consider the following
pairs:
Scheme      -        Objective
1. Multi-Modal Logistics
Park (MMLP) - Improve the logistics sector by lowering freight costs, reducing vehicular pollution, and cutting warehousing costs.
2. Bharatmala Pariyojana -- Enhance efficiency of goods and people movement with corridorbased National Highway development.
3. Pradhan Mantri Grameen
Sadak Yojana---Special provisions are made so that every village in the country is linked
to a major town by an all-season motorable road
How many of the pairs given above are correct?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is correct
• The Multi-Modal Logistics Parks (MMLPs) are being developed by the Ministry of Road, Transport
and Highways under the Bharatmala Project.
• Objective: To improve the country's logistics sector by lowering overall freight costs, reducing vehicular
pollution and congestion, and cutting warehousing costs.
• The MMLPs will provide direct connectivity to air, road, rail and waterways to the people. Recently,
the foundation stone for India's first multi-modal logistics park was laid in Assam.
• Under Phase I, 35 MMLPs are being developed, six of which are in port cities: Cochin (Kerala), Chennai
(Tamil Nadu), Vishakhapatnam (Andhra Pradesh), Mumbai (Maharashtra), Kolkata (West Bengal), and
Kandla (Gujarat).
Pair 2 is correct
• Bharatmala project is an umbrella scheme launched to enhance the efficiency of goods and people
movement across India.
• It emphasises corridor-based National Highway development to ensure infrastructure symmetry and
a consistent road user experience.
• Phase I, approved in October 2017, focuses on bridging critical infrastructure gaps by developing
34,800 km of National Highways.
• In Phase II, the government will focus on expressways and accesscontrol highways with a cumulative
length of 5,000 kilometres.
• Setubharatam Pariyojana is for the construction of about 1500 major bridges and 200 rail over bridges
rail under bridges.
Pair 3 is correct
• Pradhan Mantri Grameen Sadak Yojana: Under this scheme, special provisions are made so that every
village in the country is linked to a major town by an all-season motorable road.

Statement-I is correct, but Statement-II is incorrect.
Statement-I is incorrect, but Statement-II is correct.

questions.explanation:

• With the introduction of Bt Cotton, India is now one of the leading producers of cotton textiles.
• India is the second largest producer (~23% of global cotton production).

• India has the largest area under cotton cultivation (~38% of global cotton acreage).
• It is also the second-largest exporter (after the U.S.) and the second-largest consumer (after China).
• Top cotton producers, importers, and exporters

questions.explanation:
Brahmani is incorrect
• Brahmani river comes into existence by the confluence of the Koel and the Sankh rivers near Rourkela.

• The basin is bounded in the North by Chhotanagpur plateau, in the West and South by the Mahanadi
basin and in the East by the Bay of Bengal.

questions.question:

options.text: Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is the correct explanation for Statement-I.

Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is not the correct explanation for
Statement-I
Statement-I is correct but Statement-II is not correct
Statement-I is not correct but Statement-II is correct

questions.explanation:
Natural gas is a non-renewable, odourless, colourless, flammable, and non-toxic gaseous mixture of
hydrocarbons.
• It consists primarily of methane and ethane. Propane, butane, pentane, and hexane are also present.
(Liquefied Petroleum Gas is a mixture of butane and propane.)

• It is formed underground from the decomposition of ancient organic matter over millions of years.

• In the market, natural gas is typically traded based on its calorific value, measured in MMBTUs (millions
of British thermal units), which roughly equals 1,000 cubic feet of gas.
• The Government of India aims to increase natural gas's share of the energy mix from 6% to 15% by
2030, transforming India into a gas-based economy.

questions.question: According to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), which one of the following is the largest source of sulphur dioxide emissions?
questions.explanation: Emissions that lead to high concentrations of SO2 generally also lead to the formation of other SOx. The largest sources of SO2 emissions are from fossil fuel combustion at power plants and other industrial facilities. EPA’s national ambient air quality standards for SO2 are designed to protect against exposure to the entire group of sulfur oxides (SOx).  SO2 is the component of greatest concern and is used as the indicator for the larger group of gaseous sulfur oxides (SOx).  Other gaseous SOx (such as SO3) are found in the atmosphere at concentrations much lower than SO2.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
Statement I: India does not import apples from the United States of America.
Statement II: In India, the law prohibits the import of Genetically Modified food without the approval of the competent authority.
Which one of the following is correct in respect of the above statements?

options.text: Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II explains Statement-I.
Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct, but Statement-II does not explain Statement-I.
Statement-I is correct, but Statement-II is incorrect.
Statement-I is incorrect, but Statement-II is correct.

questions.explanation:
Statement-I is Incorrect:  Apples are one of the major imports from the USA. After India removed “retaliatory import duty” on US apples in September, imports of American apples have surged 40 times in three months, while traders are hopeful of regaining market share. In 2017-18, the import of US apples was a record of over 7 million boxes, which dropped to 50,000 boxes in the 2022–23.

Statement-II is correct: In India, the Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006, prohibits import, manufacture, use or sale of GM food without FSSAI’s approval.
